The Attorney‐General pointed out that, according to figures provided by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the change to the consumer price index numbers between June 1992 and September 1995 is calculated at approximately 9.6 per cent. This means that the value of the penalty unit has dropped.

One can only assume that if all other costs are increasing, so must the profits be from crime related activities. Therefore, it is not unreasonable that the penalty for crimes should also increase accordingly. Under the amendment proposed by this bill, the penalty unit will be increased from $100 to $110. On its own, that is not a huge jump, but the fellow earlier who was fined 100 penalty units has thus had his fine increased by $1,000. I would have to reflect that this is, in reality, a drop in the ocean. What we should have is a greater punitive and prohibitive fine, double or treble the penalty units: make the user pay, and pay dearly.

In fact, the amendments, as quoted by the Attorney‐General, will have a minor and unquantifiable financial impact on government revenue. I would have to say: why not make it a viable revenue raiser? Obviously, inflationary pressures also impact on the running of the courts and law enforcement agencies. Without these measures, the cost of catching the criminals will be extremely inhibitive and will affect the overall outcomes.

So far I have spoken on matters that focus on severer penalties for criminals. However, with any legal system there will always be a minority of innocent citizens who get caught by mistake. This bill will also amend the Extradition Act 1988 to correct deficiencies and thus lessen the likelihood of innocent citizens being held incorrectly.

The first of these amendments deals with the application of bail. Under the current system, if a magistrate remands a person in custody following the application of bail that person is not entitled to make further application for release on bail during the remand period. The original intent of this was to stop people from magistrate shopping, where someone who is refused bail by one magistrate simply asks for their case to be heard by a second and, hopefully, more lenient magistrate. The honourable member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) alluded to cases where he has had personal experience of this matter.

Unfortunately, the legislation does not allow for someone to make a further bail application, even if the person's circumstances change such that bail would be justified but the original magistrate is no longer available. This could happen if the magistrate resigned or retired. This amendment proposes that, if a person initially fails in his or her bail application on merit, he or she is not able to make a further application unless there is evidence of a change in circumstances that might justify bail being granted.

The second change to the Extradition Act 1988 relates to the procedures following the arrest of a person who has escaped from lawful custody. The intent here is quite obvious: the Attorney‐General is looking to make sure that the right person is arrested. Under the present legislation, a police officer may arrest a person without a warrant if the said officer has reasonable grounds to believe that the person has escaped from custody. That officer may arrest the person and throw them back into gaol.

BREAK.PARA: I do not want to cast aspersions on our police officers, the majority of whom do a tremendous job under very trying conditions. However, it is not inconceivable that a mistake could be made. Imagine you are walking down the street one day and suddenly a police car, sirens blaring, mounts the gutter in front of you. Two huge police officers jump out of the vehicle, guns drawn and, without getting a really good look at you, scream at you to lie face down on the footpath with your hands behind your back. Of course, you would comply with their demands for fear of being shot.

The police officers then handcuff you, throw you into the back of the vehicle and drag you down to the watch‐house where you are held. This may sound a bit far‐fetched but it could happen. If you bear a resemblance to a convicted felon who has escaped from custody, the police could possibly mistake you for that felon and put you in custody. This amendment requires that such a person be taken before a magistrate for testing of the arresting officer's belief that the person has escaped from custody. Until the magistrate is satisfied that the person has escaped from custody, no warrant can be issued.

Another section of this bill that protects the innocent is the amendment to the Proceeds of Crime Act. This amendment relates to creating a defence of reasonable corporate precaution. The Proceeds of Crime Act currently states that a body corporate is vicariously liable for the criminal conduct of its directors, servants or agents. This means that if a director or employee of a company, such as MIM, is convicted of a criminal act, the company can be held liable.

There is other Commonwealth legislation which, while establishing similar liability, provides a defence or reasonable corporate precaution. So if a company, such as MIM, can prove that it has taken reasonable precautions and, as the Attorney‐General put it, `exercised due diligence to avoid the conduct of its directors, servants and agents,' the body corporate may not be held liable. This amendment proposes to extend this to the Proceeds of Crime Act.

The other change to the Proceeds of Crime Act relates to applications for variation of restraining orders and extensions of time. The act allows for the court to restrain the property of defendants charged with serious offences. Property that remains restrained for six months after conviction is automatically forfeited to the Commonwealth. An application to have the order released or varied may be lodged but it must be listed, heard and decided within six months of the original conviction. Considerable pressure is placed on the court lists because people generally wait until the end of their trial before applying for a variation in orders. The amendments in this bill are designed to alleviate this pressure by allowing for an extension of time for the making of an application.

Another procedural change is that which will remove the necessity for ministerial consent before a prosecution can be instituted against a person suspected of a Commonwealth offence. In his second reading speech, the Attorney‐General explained that the provisions were originally enacted for the purpose of deterring private prosecution brought in inappropriate circumstances, particularly for offences which related to national security or international treaty obligations.

The Attorney‐General further explained that, since the establishment of the Office of the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions, the retention of those provisions is difficult to justify. Given that the Director of Public Prosecutions has the power to take over and discontinue a private prosecution, I would have to agree with the Attorney‐General.

I now come to the final amendment proposed by this bill. This amendment will make changes to the Witness Protection Act 1994. Before delving into the proposed changes I would like to take a minute to extol the virtues of this program. The witness protection program is vital to the continued success of our law enforcement agencies. Without this program, many of those who testify at great personal sacrifice would not be willing to go through with their testimony.

It takes a great deal of courage to testify in court, particularly in matters relating to Commonwealth criminal law. I can barely imagine what it would be like to have to testify against some of these criminals in the full knowledge that their cronies are still at large and may come looking for retribution. And after testifying, witnesses find that their lives are never the same. They may have to be relocated. Their children are ripped out of a school they may have been in for years. They may have to leave behind family and friends, and start a new career. The sacrifices these people make are immense and as such I feel it is our duty to protect them in any way we can.

The amendments proposed in this bill will make it no longer an offence for a participant in such a program, or someone who was previously a participant, to make disclosures when making a complaint to the Ombudsman, under either the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981 or the Ombudsman Act 1976. Under the current legislation such a disclosure may not be made to the Ombudsman unless prior consent has been given by the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police.

I may be corrected if I am wrong, but I believe that if you have a complaint which relates to the Federal Police you are hardly likely to want to go to them to complain. While I agree that the strictest confidentiality must be maintained with regard to the witness protection program, I would have to say that for a person to feel totally at ease they must have the right to go to the Ombudsman directly with complaints. Surely the integrity of the Ombudsman is not in question here.

As I said at the outset, I am not a lawyer nor do I pretend to have extensive knowledge of the laws of this land. However, I do feel strongly about the way our law enforcement agencies are operated. As a mother of three, a former school teacher of young children and a concerned citizen, I have a vested interest in ensuring the laws of the land are upheld. For this to be done, those who enforce the law have to have every assistance in doing so. I believe that this and other legislation being introduced by this government provides just such assistance. For that reason I commend this bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I propose to wind up the debate on the Crimes and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 and I would like to thank all of those members who have taken part in the debate. Those who have participated this morning, the members for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) and Bowman (Mrs West), both reflected concern in the community relating to law and order and security issues. In their own way they reflected also the concern that the legal system protect the innocent as well as punish the guilty.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill makes minor and technical amendments to a number of acts dealing with Commonwealth criminal and law enforcement matters. It is not, in that sense, a major policy bill. The support of the opposition for the bill is most welcome. The member for Banks (Mr Melham), who spoke for the opposition, gave conditional support to the amendment to the Crimes Act which increases the value of the penalty unit from $100 to $110 in accordance with the consumer price index. The concern he expressed was also reflected by the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith).

Monetary penalties in terms of penalty units were first introduced in 1992. That approach allows a range of monetary penalties to be monitored and amended simultaneously by a single amendment to the value of the penalty unit in the Crimes Act. Where a particular offence is isolated and identified as requiring an increase in penalty, that is achieved by increasing the number of penalty units attached to that offence.

The value of the penalty unit has remained unchanged since 1992. Given that the CPI increased by 9.6 per cent between June 1992 and September 1995, it is considered appropriate that the value of the penalty unit be increased. The amendment to the value ensures that the level of monetary penalties for Commonwealth offences is uniform and consistent.

The member for Bowman mentioned the possibility of double or treble penalty units. The question of whether to increase the value of a penalty unit by doubling or trebling it raises complex policy and practical issues which really could not appropriately be dealt with in a portfolio bill such as this. This bill is intended only to effect minor policy and technical amendments.

The government welcomes the support of the opposition for the amendment which corrects a deficiency in subsection 15(3) of the Extradition Act 1988. It is important that, where a person whose extradition is sought has unsuccessfully applied for bail, the person be able to apply again for bail if there is evidence of a change in circumstances which might justify bail being granted.

The member for Banks and the member for Dickson also mentioned the retrospective application of the amendments to the International War Crimes Tribunals Act. The paragraphs in question are technical amendments to correct a typographical error in the 1995 amendments to the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987. In each case, section 46 of the International War Crimes Tribunals Act 1995 was referred to, whereas the correct reference should have been to section 45.

Legal advice was obtained following discovery of the errors to the effect that it is likely that a court would regard the incorrect reference as a patent mistake and interpret the amendment as referring to section 45 and not section 46.

Section 45 enables the Director of Public Prosecutions to apply for registration in a specified court of a forfeiture order made in relation to property believed to be in Australia when so requested by the International Tribunal for the Prosecution of Persons Responsible for Serious Violations of International Humanitarian Law Committed in the Territory of the Former Yugoslavia since 1991, or by the International Criminal Tribunal for the Prosecution of Persons Responsible for Genocide and other Serious Violations of International Humanitarian Law Committed in the Territory of Rwanda. So we are talking about two tribunals—the former Yugoslavia tribunal and the Rwanda tribunal.

No applications for registration of tribunal forfeiture orders have been received by my department from either of the tribunals. I am advised that there is none under consideration at this time. In these circumstances, no personal rights and liberties will be adversely affected by the amendments contained in the bill. So the retrospectivity is of no consequence.

The amendment to the Customs Act in the bill makes provision for the Australian Federal Police to recover the costs it incurs in relation to the transportation, storage, custody and control of vessels used in drug trafficking. This was referred to by the member for Bowman. In the course of the debate, the member for Dickson asked whether cost recovery would extend to the travel costs of the AFP where those costs relate to the transportation and the taking control of vessels used in drug trafficking. The amendment is framed broadly so that any costs, charges and expenses incurred by the AFP in that context are recoverable.

Amendments to the Proceeds of Crime Act create a defence of reasonable corporate precaution. The amendment makes provision for the defence of reasonable precaution to prevent the conduct of the body corporate's directors, servants or agents from being attributed to it, if it can establish that it took reasonable precautions and exercised due diligence to avoid the conduct. In response to the member for Dickson's questions concerning that amendment, it is for the body corporate to raise and to prove the defence. The requisite standard of proof is `the balance of probabilities'.

Schedule 2 to the bill removes the requirement to obtain ministerial consent to institute proceedings for the prosecution of offences under the acts denoted in the schedule. The member for Dickson, who seems to have asked quite a lot of questions in the debate, asked whether the amendment enables a private citizen to initiate a prosecution. Private prosecutions may be instituted, which might previously have been blocked by the consent provisions.

However, as pointed out by the member for Bowman, the DPP has the power, under the Director of Public Prosecutions Act, to take over a prosecution on indictment for offences against laws of the Commonwealth where the prosecution has been instituted by someone other than the Attorney‐General. The DPP could therefore take over the prosecution and effectively terminate it. That power provides a safeguard against the continuation of prosecutions which do not comply with the prosecution policy of the Commonwealth. The government is indebted to contributions from members in the debate and I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 December 1996, on motion by Mr Prosser:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill in that it introduces a number of technical and drafting corrections. Firstly, it incorporates name changes to about 350 tariff classifications, which were recommended by the world customs organisations, but the current levels of tariff assistance are to be maintained. It also makes minor amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1995 to correct drafting, formatting and spelling anomalies in the act when it replaced the Customs Tariff Act 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: Importantly, it corrects now to allow goods sent overseas for repair not able to be carried out in Australia to be allowed back into Australia with just the cost of the repair dutiable and not the value of the entire item. This apparently was the effect of some inadvertent drafting in the earlier act, and the effect of this change commences from 15 July 1997.

It also reduces the duty on aviation fuels by 0.75 per cent per litre, due to over‐recovery during the 1995‐96 year of the aviation industry's contribution to air safety costs. It also introduces a phase back to the general tariff of five per cent for goods which were unintentionally included at the 15 per cent rate, for certain automotive parts and certain textile applications.

Finally, it reimposes the general five per cent tariff on a range of plastics previously exempted under the Canada‐Australia trade agreement. The government, it would appear, has been persuaded by Australian industry that Canadian manufacturers had an unfair advantage over their Australian counterparts and has, accordingly, through this, reimposed the tariff. The opposition sees these as sensible corrections. We support the proposed changes and lend our support to the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone, Sharman, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to support the amendments to the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996. This bill amends the 1995 act to enact measures introduced earlier into the House of Representatives as customs tariff proposals. These amendments are drafted twice yearly to maintain some 350 tariff classifications recommended by the World Customs Organisation, to which Australia is a contracting party. There are also a further 200 Australian classifications which make up our own tariff program.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1988, Australia adopted a new classification system for administering imports and for collecting and presenting foreign trade statistics. This new system—the harmonised commodity and coding system—has been developed over a number of years by an international body, the Customs Cooperation Council, of which Australia is a member.

The new international harmonised system, sponsored by the WCO in Brussels, replaces the tailored Australian tariff system, with domestic subheadings, with a universal six‐digit code. The first six figures of each classification are taken from the international system and the seventh and eighth figures are for Australia to insert. These seventh and eighth figures provide a separate category while under the same tariff grouping, making it possible for Australia to impose its own domestically determined tariff system.

A universal coding system is essential in the new world of international trade where countless goods are traded between countries and categories are proliferating. The new system incorporates new products that have come into the international trade market in recent years. Value added, technically advanced products and components emerge without a suitable tariff concession to cater for them. This requires the introduction of new classifications. So Australia has adopted the classification changes as agreed and formalised by the principal Customs Tariffs Act in 1995, and it has added 200 national tariff splits to maintain its tariff program. These biyearly amendments are therefore necessary for the efficient and effective administration of our customs.

Schedule 1 of the bill is one of four schedules, and is mainly editorial amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1995. The other schedules, however, have some important provisions. For example, the rates of duty for beer, spirits, tobacco products and certain petroleum products are the subject of half‐yearly adjustments in line with movements in the consumer price index, so this amendment reflects the increase which came into operation on 1 February 1996. This amendment will also provide for the tariff treatment of topped crude oil. A reference to topped crude oil was inadvertently omitted in the newer 1995 act.
A new tariff structure for newsprint preserves existing rates of duty but complies with the WCO changes on the definition of newsprint—and this is also included in the amendment.

Schedule 2 is significant and related to goods repaired overseas, a matter already referred to by the member for Hotham (Mr Crean). The schedule amends the concessional entry of goods which have been sent overseas for repair when those repairs could not be carried out in Australia. Previous to this amendment, an importer has been required to pay duty on the value of the exported articles as well as duty on the repair cost. Administrative procedures have been implemented to ensure that customs duty will be collected only on the repair cost of the imported goods. This amendment gives legal effect to the administrative action taken on 15 July 1996.

BREAK.PARA: The principal act originally tightened the eligibility definition in respect of goods that were exported from Australia to be altered overseas. Some manufacturers took advantage of a system where they could send materials overseas to be enhanced or further manufactured using relatively cheap foreign labour. They then enjoyed a duty‐free return of the goods to Australia, so a more rigid definition was introduced to discourage this practice. The principal act now only provides for the duty‐free importation of goods replaced under a safety recall. It includes goods which are being sent to consumers to compensate them for a product they have already purchased which has a design fault or safety concern.

This amendment will also allow for the duty‐free return of goods which are part of a process to replace goods exported from Australia for repair or renovation, and will provide for a duty on the price of the repair or renovation only.

Schedule 3 of the bill is to do with the aviation industry and it is to do with the aviation fuel excise. Avgas is the fuel used in piston engine propeller aircraft, and is most commonly used by the general aviation industry. Avtur is used in jet aircraft and turbine powered propeller aircraft.

There was an amendment to the Customs Tariff Act of 1995, which came into operation on 1 September 1996, reducing the per litre duty on aviation gasoline—avgas—and avtur. This reduction in aviation fuel excise will return more than $13 million in savings to the aviation industry in 1996‐97. The entire excise on aviation fuel is distributed by the Commonwealth to two aviation authorities. The Civil Aviation Safety Authority—CASA—is responsible for air safety regulation and Airservices Australia—AA—provides air traffic control services, air navigation facilities, rescue and firefighting services. These two authorities were created in 1995 by the division of the Civil Aviation Authority.

The reduction in excise follows a 1995‐96 over recovery of contributions from the aviation industry for operating costs of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. The total funding for CASA for the 1995‐96 financial year was $86.3 million. Of this, 40 per cent was funded by the government. Of the remaining funding, 55 per cent was met through a levy on the aviation fuels and $4.9 million is expected to be contributed through fees for services provided by the industry.

This funding is broadly based on a model where the users of aviation and the beneficiaries of aviation safety contribute directly to the costs. The general public contributes to this via the government appropriation, the travelling public by the excise on aviation fuels, and the aviation industry by the excise on aviation fuels and by direct regulatory service fees.

Revenue from excise on aviation fuels was greater than budgeted, reflecting higher than expected growth in domestic airline activity. So this reduction rightfully returns those moneys to the industry, consistent with the government's commitment to fair and equitable charging arrangements. Last year, when the coalition was in opposition, we opposed the then Labor government's plans for an increase in the excise on avgas.

Beneficiaries of this reduction in flying costs will in particular be regional and commuter airlines, flying training schools and operators of agricultural and charter aircraft throughout Australia—and no‐one needs to be reminded of how significant that aviation is for rural and regional development. The reduction in excise on aviation fuels will also directly benefit the more than 20,000 private pilots, and help the major and regional airlines keep downward pressure on air fares, benefiting the travelling public.

Both avtur and avgas aircraft operators contribute to an excise which is allocated to CASA. Avtur operators, the jet aircraft, pay for the air traffic services they use through a system of charges to AA—a user‐pays approach. The contribution is in the form of on route charges. Jet aircraft tend to adhere to nominated flight plans. However, avgas users, or smaller craft operators, generally do not use scheduled flight plans and a further excise has been imposed on the avgas fuel to recover their air navigation control costs to Airservices Australia. International craft pay an international aircraft charge in lieu of the excise. Our government is also progressing the planned development of long‐term funding arrangements for CASA later this year, with a view to their implementation in next year's budget, but this amendment has not reduced funding to CASA in 1996‐97.

In general, the international harmonisation of tariff classifications—that is, the focus of the amendments in this bill—makes it easier for exporters to participate in international markets. It minimises the costs to exporters by decreasing paperwork and research, makes it easier to research new markets, and makes it quicker for a new industry or small business person to understand, learn and grow a market share. The amendments provide a simpler and a more understandable process for those who administer the Customs Act. The harmonised system also greatly facilitates the collection and interpretation of all foreign trade statistics. It is essential for Australia to monitor trends in world trade so we can take advantage of emerging opportunities as we develop appropriate marketing strategies.

The coalition supported the implementation of a new tariff classification regime in 1995 in order that Australia would become a cooperative and efficient player in world trade. We must not jeopardise Australia's ability to meet its international agreements, especially in respect of trade, and we must maintain our reputation as a facilitator of trade.

The government aims to secure the best possible conditions and opportunities for Australian businesses trading and investing overseas. International trade is no longer the sole domain of large companies. There are now more than 4½ thousand small and medium sized businesses actively engaged in export markets, and their numbers are growing. There is no longer any relationship between being big and succeeding; small players can also grow and succeed. They generate some $6.5 billion a year in international turnover and, of course, there are many jobs on the home front. Australia's tariff reform has played a major role in promoting the restructure of Australian industry, promoting world best practice and competitiveness and encouraging Australian firms to pursue export markets. I therefore strongly support the Customs Tariffs Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Prosser, Geoff, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr PROSSER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I would like to thank the speakers for their input into the debate. The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1996, which is now before the committee, contains a number of amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1995. In the main, the proposals incorporated in this bill are technical measures and they fall into four parts. Schedule 1 is a series of amendments which were made in the Customs Tariff Proposal No. 1 (1996) to ensure that details contained in the Customs Tariff Act 1995 were correct when it commenced on 1 July 1996. The changes contain editorial amendments, the transfer of legislative amendments, which were enacted late in 1995 but not incorporated in the new legislation, and three tariff structural refinements to accord with the previous government's requirement that duty rates remain stable.

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule 2 of this bill is operative from 15 July 1996. This contains consequential changes as a result of amendments to the tariff concession system. Item 19 in part 2 of schedule 4 allows the concessional entry of goods which have been sent overseas for repair that cannot be carried out in Australia. The amendments contained, change the previous bill which would have meant that importers would have to pay duty on the value of exported articles in addition to that on the repair costs.

Administrative procedures were implemented to ensure that customs duty was only collected on the repair cost of the reimported goods. This amendment gives legal effect to the administrative action on 15 July 1996. Schedule 3 of the bill is operative from 1 September 1996. On 20 August 1996, my colleague the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, John Sharp, announced a reduction of 0.75 cents per litre on the duty on aviation gasoline and aviation kerosene. The duty reductions stem from the over recovery during 1995‐96 of the aviation industry's contribution to the operating costs of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority.

The industry contribution is collected by the Commonwealth through a levy included in the customs and excise duty on aviation fuels. This reduction will deliver savings of more than $13 million to the industry in 1996‐97. This is consistent with the government's commitment to fair and equitable safety regulation cost recovery arrangements. The other changes contained in the bill are of an administrative nature and have no duty implications. I commend the bill to the Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 December 1996, on motion by Mr Anderson:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe, Neil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition has indicated that we are comfortable with this legislation and, of course, that is why it is being debated in this chamber. We accept that the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill and the operations of the scheme, since it has been in place, have now to a large extent been superseded by funding through the drought relief scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: I might say that I can well remember the angst that surrounded the introduction of this legislation. I remember a very late night sitting of the House of Representatives in the legislation's passage at a time when we were seeing a substantial downturn in commodity prices and a lot of difficulty, particularly in the agriculture sector. There was clearly a need to introduce measures that made it easier for farm households to gain financial support, while various income tests and assets tests were being applied. It was something that the Labor government of the day worked through and put in place in an attempt to make that easier.

It still continued to have its administrative difficulties and, to some extent, I think what has now come into place through the drought relief scheme meets those needs and therefore this legislation is really redundant. But we are quite comfortable in going with the flow on this one.

I might take the opportunity, while speaking on farm household support and with some indulgence from the chair, to raise an issue that is causing me a little bit of concern at the moment in central Victoria and in other parts of regional Victoria. We have all seen the need for farm households and rural communities in particular to become much more innovative in finding new ways to source income and in Victoria one such interesting innovation has been the establishment of the concept of Teletrack which is to expand the racing industry into televised formula presented racing, particularly for the Asian satellite market and elsewhere. In many communities in regional Victoria, there has been a very strong and favourable response to the development of this plan.

We have run into a bit of a problem though in that the Victorian government, which in the end has to give final approval, is now sitting on a report which I understand recommends that we proceed with this industry. There are lots of rural towns which are saying, `Yes, please do so as quickly as possible.' In the central highlands, in the goldfields local government region, it is my understanding that the commissioners want to approve it and go on with it. Lots of farms, which are now involved in this industry, are very keen about it.

I am raising as a matter of concern, while I have the opportunity to say a few words, the fact that the state minister has not made the decision to approve this. This appears to be because of pressure from the VRC, which is not happy with the competition, obviously. I understand that the commissioners have now received a letter from the planning minister directing them to abandon this plan and revealing, I guess, the hint that if the commissioners do not agree, then they may in fact be replaced by an administrator and the move back to local government elections postponed even more.

I can only say in this forum that this is a classic example of people in rural and regional areas—where necessity is the mother of invention—being forced to find innovative ways to bring their communities back to life. With the changes that have taken place in the economic field here in towns such as Bairnsdale, Lakes Entrance, Maryborough, Hamilton and Portland, as well as in central Victoria, this is one such industry that has been won, and it is highly desired. I would certainly call on the Victorian state racing minister, Tom Reynolds—whom I know personally and have dealt with for many years on a very friendly basis—to get on with the approval. If, under the influence of the VRC, the government is trying to sit on it, I call on him to very quickly correct the situation.

I note also that the Premier of Victoria is away. They always say down there that when the cat is away the mice will play, and so I guess we will need Jeff back soon to straighten this out. I understand that he is very strongly in favour of Teletrack, and wants to see it up and running. So, for all sorts of reasons, I am saying today, `Get on with it.' As I have said, the opposition is very comfortable with the changes that are involved in the legislation. We are not opposing it.

We are awaiting with interest the outcome of the review that Senator Newman has in place to look at the application of the assets test and the income test to farm based properties, because that is directly relevant to household support and to income flows in difficult times. We wait to see what sorts of solutions come from that report and, in the interim, we are very happy for this legislation to proceed, acknowledging that Labor's farm household support scheme has really now run its race and has been superseded by the drought relief scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Causley, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I note that the opposition is not going to oppose the rather minor amendments to the legislation which the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill 1996 addresses. It is meant to tidy up a situation which has evolved over the last while with the farm community. You have to go back a little in history to look closely at what has happened. I suppose that it goes back to about 1989 when there was an agreement between the states and the Commonwealth. At one of their ministerial meetings, the Commonwealth put forward that drought no longer be considered a natural disaster. Until that particular time, it was considered to be a natural disaster.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the facts were that there was an agreement that, having withdrawn drought as a natural disaster, certain other things needed to be put in place. The Commonwealth did agree that there would be changes—particularly in the taxation area, where farmers would be able to set aside money in the good years to tide them over the uncontrollable drought periods that occur in this country—and also other incentives whereby they would be encouraged to preserve water and fodder on their properties in order to better manage their properties so that they would not have to come back to the taxpayer in such times.

Unfortunately, when I was the Minister for Agriculture in New South Wales and we struck the terrible drought around 1992, none of these things were in place, and so we had an extreme problem as to how we were going to accommodate people who were in dire distress. There was no doubt about it: some of them did not have any money to put food on the table, and they were in extreme circumstances. I pay tribute to the then federal minister for primary industry, Senator Collins, who, when I approached him, did put in place a scheme which was very helpful to farming families. I suppose it is the scheme that we are phasing out now because it has been superseded.

The point is that it is important, and I think that the present minister has addressed the problem in setting up the rural task force. Some people in the community would say, `How is the farming community so different from small business? They work along similar lines and they can probably get into the same types of financial problems.' As I mentioned before, one of the unique things about the farming community is that they have to put up with the vagaries of the seasons, and no matter how much budgeting you do, if you do get into these circumstances where the seasons turn against you, of course, it puts you in a very serious situation.

When it comes back to getting some support, they do not have the ability to get support because they are considered to have an asset. The asset might be encumbered, it might be very encumbered, but they are considered to have an asset. So it does cause a problem when you are trying to give some relief to people who are in very serious and necessitous circumstances.

The rural task force has addressed some of those issues as to how that can be considered. Quite frankly, the most important point is to try to make farmers self‐sufficient. You are not going to support everyone. There is no doubt that in any business some are going to fail and some are not going to be economic producers. That is a fact of life. But the majority of good managers, the majority of good producers, should not be driven out because of the nature of Australia, which is the driest inhabited continent on earth, and it certainly causes some very distressing problems from time to time.

This is rather minor legislation. It is addressing a few of the issues that have become redundant. However, I do urge the parliament to consider, very closely, the report that is going to come from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Anderson, on this rural task force. Anyone who represents a rural seat will understand exactly what we are talking about. I believe the majority of Australians really understand and are very sympathetic to the way that farmers have to put up with the vagaries of the seasons and the hardships they go through in the rural and regional areas of Australia. I honestly believe that when we need to put in place legislation that will support them, this parliament and the people of Australia will support it.

I do not want to go too far into the reports of the rural task force. I think the time will come when we can debate that. As I said, this is minor legislation. I am pleased to see that the opposition is supporting it and I commend it to the parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As the previous speaker said in speaking to this bill, the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill, these are minor amendments. I must say that the farm household support scheme was applicable to very few. There were very few who actually took it up. Because it was under close scrutiny, the ability to rort the system was very limited indeed. There was very little rorting, so little that it did not warrant supervision. This is not so with many of the other social security forms of relief that are given to people.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that this country any longer realises the full significance of farm support. When you support a farming family, you do not just support that family, you actually support a country town. If you look at Australia you see the enormous drift from country towns to the cities occurring everywhere. It imposes additional strains on the whole community because when someone goes to the city—our cities are by and large bursting at the seams—you require new infrastructure. The cost of providing that new infrastructure is quite significant and is borne by the general community. Quite clearly, in the national interest it is worth preserving the country towns. It is also worth preserving them for the lifestyle and the contribution that country people make in giving stability and perhaps an element of commonsense to political discussion that is not generally available in the cities.

I do not believe the drought relief scheme fully replaces the household support scheme. People could get household support for reasons which did not pertain to drought—things like commodity prices and the actions of a rapacious banking system.

I have the problem also that there are many farm families where the application of the job search allowance would be highly justifiable. Very many social security outlets do not understand the application of this act with respect to farmers and often you find it very difficult to get this applied to farm families. This is something that certainly needs looking at. I know it occurs in Western Australia and I would be surprised if it did not occur in every other state, in that a lot of Social Security officers do not understand the particular situation of farmers.

There is no doubt that we do everything we can to keep our farm sector viable. I am not sure that is understood today by any of the major parties. As an example, the government parties are, I suspect, going to vote to abolish the present tariff on sugar. That would make Australia susceptible to imports from the European Common Market, where the tariff subsidy range is close to 200 per cent. It is quite conceivable that Europe will use that for political reasons, and we could see sugar coming to Australia. That will be an absurd situation. It will benefit the consumer not at all. All it will do is put a little extra money in the pockets of the mainly multinationals who are the very big consumers of sugar in the country.

It will, of course, flow on. They will say, `If we have taken the step with sugar and we have made the sugar industry even more efficient, we can then apply this in other areas.' If the government goes ahead and supports a reduction of tariff on sugar it is inconceivable that it will not likewise support a reduction in the tariff on motor vehicles. In my view, that would be an absolute disaster and an irresponsible act.

This tariff reduction on sugar is supported, I understand, by the grower groups. They simply, in my view, do not understand their own situation or their own best interests. They feel that they are protecting their domestic arrangements from Hilmer, when what we ought to do as a government is tackle the nonsense that is Hilmer.

There is nothing in this bill that you can substantially oppose. It is a relatively small amendment. I will be watching it very closely to make sure there is in fact no diminution of assistance to country people. As the previous speaker said, there are always people at the margins in farming and you cannot protect them all. The truth is that in the rural communities we have had an ongoing loss averaging over 10 per cent. There has always been that action, I guess, of the market filtering out the incompetent and, in some cases, the unlucky. Unfortunately, in recent times it has also filtered out the young, aggressive farmer who is trying to get things done, often taking bank advice and extending himself—on bank advice—beyond his capabilities. He has subsequently been sold up by banks. So we have actually tended to filter some more aggressive farmers by this process.

The importance of the rural sector is, I think, not generally understood in Australia. Both political parties have to sit down and have a good hard think about whether we do want farming in Australia as it exists now or whether we are going to be content in the future with corporate farming. That is a move that I would oppose very strongly as I see it not in our national interests, as it clearly has not been in the national interests of the United States.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forrest, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that the intention of the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill has not been misunderstood by the parliament given that, fundamentally, it is removing the entitlement for people to receive farm household support. I am very pleased that it has not been seen in isolation on that element. I am delighted that the emphasis of the government is now on establishing the comprehensive rural policy which the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) referred to.

SPEECH.PARA: Rural adjustment is a massive issue around the world. There is no doubt about that. The drive towards greater efficiency in primary production produces the need for economies of scale, and that is putting intolerable pressure on rural communities because it essentially causes population depletion.

Last year I had the benefit of taking part in an official parliamentary delegation to the European institutions. It was quite enlightening. In every discussion we had—whether it was with the European Parliament, the OECD or any of the European institutions to which we pay particular attention—when we raised the issue of the common agricultural policy, it was referred to as their rural policy.

We made the point about the damage that subsidised commodities can have on the markets in which we are trying to compete and how that hurts us badly. That comment was often received with the comment, `Well, we're not as silly as you Australians.' We were always urging them to shift the emphasis from price support to income support. I discovered that Ireland was the home of support for the CAP. They fiercely defended this as their rural policy, despite the fact that it is a huge cost to taxpayers and that it props up inefficient agriculture.

A massive review is now being undertaken by the government of the provision of caring social security in rural environments—and the member for Page (Mr Causley) mentioned the rural task force, and we have had a rural finance summit, and it is pleasing to see that emphasis—but it should be noted that it is not always drought which puts pressure on primary industry producing families.

I was born and raised in the country. In fact, the incubator for John Forrest was the dried fruit industry and horticulture in general. The greatest bogy for somebody trying to produce the best quality, five‐crown dried sultana, which receives a premium price particularly in European markets, is rain, particularly at this time of the year as we commence the harvest. One of the Comcar drivers was commenting this morning on how delighted he was that it was raining. Rain in January and February can create disasters for horticulture.

I recall an occasion as a young lad where, on a modest 36 acres—which was a sizeable suite of properties 25 or 30 years ago—we thought we had our El Dorado sitting there on the vines. My father was so pleased. We put on extra harvest labour to get the crop off quickly in order to get it dried, into the cooperative and ready for packing, because that is when you can consider it is safe. It is like getting your wheat in the silo. It is not safe until it is there.

We harvested this record crop and put it onto the drying racks. We filled the final rack and went home to celebrate and relax because we had it on the racks and had finished the primary stage. That night we had 2½ inches of rain. We had so much rain that the bottom of the drying green was covered with 18 inches of water and, although they were substantial steel structures, one rack collapsed and about three tonnes of fruit fell into the water. That evening, for the first time in my life—and I have never forgotten the impact it had—I saw my father cry. Here was our El Dorado, the prospect of a good price for the crop, ruined by rain.

The risk from rain still continues. Very often, many of my horticulturists are put under pressure not as a result of drought, but because of the opposite. It happens with many other commodities. With table grapes, and even wine grapes, adverse wet weather has a very dramatic impact on the quality and quantity of fruit produced and, therefore, affects incomes. I will be pleased to see that that aspect is also included in the comprehensive review that is going on.

We should be proud in Australia of the reputation of having a comprehensive social security policy. I have a citizen in my electorate who was widowed two years ago. She is an American, but has become an Australian citizen. Originally, her contact was just to brief me and advise me that, with the support she was receiving, although it was sizeable, it was difficult for her to manage a family of three boys and all of their education expenses. In assisting her to understand the process, I advised her that social security was not designed to allow Australian families to live a lifestyle of luxury; it was set at targeted levels to make sure that the needs of families were met. She commented to me that the US social security system came nowhere near what Australia provided, and I was encouraged by that approach.

Last week, I had the good fortune in Washington to attend some discussions with congressmen in association with the festivities for the new Congress and the State of the Union address by the President of the United States. I entered into some discussions about concerns I have with the new US farm bill and the export enhancement program that is included in that, with a massive budget—of $500 million—proposed for it again this year. That approach was referred to as their rural policy and it poses a great challenge for Australians.

I am not advocating that we move into any level of subsidising inefficient agriculture in any way. But there are rural families hurting out there who have enormous pressures in educating our children—bearing in mind that securing a post‐secondary education for many rural families involves sending them away to provincial cities and metropolitan centres to pursue their tertiary education. This often involves enormous expense. So when the social security system looks at their asset base and says, `You have sizeable assets in your farming assets. You have the means to educate your own children,' what needs to be kept in mind is that often that large asset is propped up by a very large debt at dangerous equity levels. It is very difficult for families to consider going to the bank and borrowing more money when they are already at marginal equity levels.

The member for Kalgoorlie talked about those who can be lucky. One of the things about primary production is that, if things go well, often it does amount to luck. An aggressive young farmer who wants to have a go has to take a punt; he has to take a risk. While the situation in my electorate for primary production is nowhere near what it is in Queensland and northern New South Wales after five years of drought there, the good year only comes along once every three or four years. To say to the farming community, `In your good times, you should put away to cope with the bad,' is often unrealistic, given their current equity situation.

I am pleased to see that there is a positiveness about what the government is doing. Like all members who represent rural constituencies, we watch with great interest the outcome of the final recommendations of the rural task force. We watch with great interest the activities of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) in addressing this very question to ensure that, as a nation, we have a caring approach to those needy families involved in primary production, and yet that we continue the good work that is being done to encourage efficiency in agriculture so that we can get into those valuable export markets and compete.

Despite what is often a very negative discussion, I remain confident and ever hopeful about the prospects for rural Australia. We have great potential, and one of the greatest assets is the nature of the people that live out there. They are, just by nature of their pioneering character, a very positive and resilient people. We need to recognise this and do what we can to arrest the dramatic decline in population centres out there. More importantly, we must meet the very immediate concerns of working‐class, very hardworking Australians. I look forward to further progress on these matters. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Farm Household Support Bill, introduced in 1992, was to provide loans for certain farmers who could not obtain a loan through normal means and also provide for the conversion in certain circumstances of such a loan to a grant when a farmer sold his or her farm. No‐one should have any objection to a continuation of this scheme, given the parlous state of much of our rural industry, but the farm household support scheme is to be terminated to make budget savings of $960,000. This perhaps indicates the scheme was not accessed to the degree it might have been, given the needs of many rural families for financial assistance, but to dismantle it seems premature, for reasons I will detail.

SPEECH.PARA: By way of background, let me read into Hansard a letter from a farmer in the central west who wrote to me recently with a not atypical example of life down on the farm 1997 style. This gentleman says:

I've been a farmer and my own boss and on the same property for 41 years and I've never seen it as bad as far as cost‐price squeeze is concerned, the disillusionment of the people and working longer and harder than ever for what?

I am not talking about farmers who have larger holdings and have never had to purchase more land to improve their position or get their sons established. I'm talking about the average family farm, in most cases a fairly big debt (thanks to Mr Keating and the huge interest rate hike a few years back) and what used to be a comfortable living.
The letter goes on to say:

The costs of everything (and I mean everything) just keep increasing and our income dropping alarmingly. Peter this cannot continue, in a matter of a few years there will be no family farms as we know it today.

I suppose we live in a favourable area, on the river, but I've lived here all my life and know the people and there are farms for sale everywhere, and in some cases have been taken over by banks and the young farmers and families having to leave. To me this is disastrous—but who the hell cares, we've gradually been reduced to peasants, producing cheap food and to the governing bodies that's about all that matters.

This letter is from the heartland of the safe, once financially lucrative central west of New South Wales, where the topsoil is metres deep, where the rivers flow by, where lucerne flats should return a premium product that supports not only the farm family but a significant portion of the local economy as well. That is how it used to be. My correspondent goes on:

We (my son and myself and our families) produce 200 odd head of cattle—the income drop this year over last year will be at least $20,000. This year we grew 200 tonnes of barley, last year we got $170 a tonne in the paddock—this year we get $108 a tonne, a drop of $62 a tonne, or nearly $12,500. We grow roughly 500 tonnes of lucerne. This year we are taking $20 a tonne less—another $10,000 down. So you see there is over $42,000 drop in income this year—about a third of our GROSS.
He goes on:

I wonder what other sections of our community would tolerate this. Can you imagine cutting school teachers, union wages by one third, wouldn't there be a human outcry? But we have to sit back and take it and I'm telling you Peter the people are sick of it and they won't tolerate it, seeing their livelihood eroded to the point where it is just not viable. Don't think I am a whingeing farmer, I'm not, I'm just stating facts. I know it is alright to say we have to get our commodity prices up, sure, but there has to be a reduction in our costs also. You'll have to hammer and hammer our cause to the appropriate heads of Government—we don't seem to able to do it.

That is not an isolated cry from the wilderness. That is the family farm, Australia 1997: a situation borne not of a lack of commitment, heartache, effort, sweat and pain from the man—and the lady—on the land but from a system that has deserted him or her, a financial system that has abandoned the farm sector in tough times after screwing every last dollar from the land.

Mr Keating and Labor stand condemned for using the blunt tool of interest rate manipulation to force up to Shylock rates the cost of money to farmers, a debt that many are still struggling to meet—quite apart from those who were wiped off the rural landscape by the combination of interest rates, the commodity price crash and the distortion of the so‐called level playing field trading arrangements that we so naively adhere to while our trading partners wear the grid‐iron gear on this field, have the football, and change the rules as the game progresses, to suit themselves.

I note the words of the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Forrest) about the US farm bill. We all know how uneven that playing field is. The forecast from the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics reinforces the frustration my farming correspondent so eloquently detailed in his letter. He cited cattle prices. Unless we take control of this industry ourselves—the value adding component as well—and are not just a bottom‐end price taker supplying product, with no control over prices, to vertically integrated foreign‐owned abattoir feedlot export consortia—then the family farm is doomed, and the skills and dedication of the farm family go with it.

All this is highly relevant to the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill under discussion. Unless we restructure farm finance in this country to help fill the void left by the banks' abandonment of the bush, we will most likely see not only bandaid schemes such as farm household support reintroduced, but also the need for massive bandaging to stop the haemorrhaging that is likely to occur in rural Australia unless our terms of trade improve.

BREAK.PARA: In this regard, the way in which the banks have abandoned the bush is an absolute disgrace. Not only have they headed off to greener pastures, aided by the total deregulatory climate allowed by the Labor government and its successor, but they have removed much of their advisory services from not only regional centres but also certainly the small local branch, where face‐to‐face contact with the bank manager had become part and parcel of the family farm's financial planning process. At the time the banker was needed most—at the time of high interest rates, dropping commodity prices, the drought, and the slump in wool—the bank johnnies left town. That is no fault of theirs: they were rationalised out of existence while the bank bosses told deputations from councils in my area to go home and stop wasting their time.

There are those who want to invest in the viability of the family farm because they believe it is the heart and soul of Australian enterprise. They do not believe the economic rationalist argument that `get big or get out' is the only answer. There are those in regional centres who are exploring alternative schemes of farm finance that will bypass the major banks and their usury attitudes. They will probably require government support for some underwriting of their proposal, but it will be public money well provided, because it is pro‐active support to help farmers at grassroots level.

I do, however, despair of the interest that this government will show in such proposals, if they were floated—so desperate is the government not to underwrite debt. Yet such schemes as household support, rural adjustment and exceptional circumstances assistance are all reactionary programs after the horse has bolted, so to speak. We need some proactive support from government for the family farm.

As well, there are those in the superannuation industry who are exploring the potential of supporting rural infrastructure programs, particularly rural specific superannuation schemes. They want to support perhaps those viable farm enterprises that have potential, while credit unions are helping fill the void left by the banks, at least for some small businesses in smaller towns, and are helping farm families with their smaller financial commitments. All power to those alternative credit providers.

The horror days of the Keating bank rates are, hopefully, behind us. Hopefully, we can safely put farm household support schemes in the bottom drawer. But let us not be fooled that the recent reduction in interest rates heralds an end to the problems of the farm family. Such families are now being caught up in the sticky web of the actual means test for Austudy if their children or one of their adult members wants to improve their educational standard.

Why is that? It is because no‐one outside the farm community, certainly not the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) or her bureaucrats, understands that most farm families are trying to earn some supplementary income off farm. Income becomes expenditure to keep the farm family on the farm and meet the repair and maintenance. Family farm partnerships are a fact of life. They are not a rort, they are not a void into which off‐farm income is dumped to avoid taxation or any other responsibilities; they are very real. Off‐farm income is an essential part of the family farm these days—it is not some scheme to manipulate government assistances. Yet families are being penalised at the moment by their very off‐farm endeavours and they are by the score being disqualified from access to Austudy.

The farm household support scheme is to be terminated due to the very low demand and is a contribution to meeting the government's fiscal target, which has somewhat blown out again. I am pleased to see that the government will meet existing commitments for support and continue to accept applications until these legislative changes are effected.

The government says in its budget papers that it expects there to be a minimal impact from the termination of the FHS. There has been a steady decline in the number of recipients since mid‐1994, when there were only 284. At budget time last year there were about 47. The government assures us that the welfare needs of farmers will be addressed by the special rural task force.

Let us not be fooled by the reduction in applicants for the farm household support. That decline was in direct proportion to a levelling off in bank interest rates. Farm families are particularly proud. They access welfare as an absolutely last resort. They cannot stomach being, on the one hand, part of the hands‐on productive effort of this nation and, on the other hand, lining up for welfare. Sure, there were times when it was easy to accuse the farmer of capitalising the gains and socialising the losses—the `agrarian socialist' tag—with the bounties, the tax write‐offs. For the average family farm those times, if they ever existed at all, are well gone. Yet few are putting their hands out for help unless there is a desperate need.

The termination of the farm household support should be a signal that things are improving in the bush. They are not. We had a reasonable return from the recent harvest but that too was somewhat illusory. The returns were based on a very modest price for a phenomenally large harvest. Had the yields been average or poor, the cash flows of the family farms would still be in dire straits.

That is why we must quickly redress the anomalies of the current Austudy mess. That is why we must revisit the six months extension of the exceptional drought circumstances assistance measures, because one good season will not end the money drought. And that is why we should be pro‐active in examining ways government can underwrite alternative financial avenues for the family farm, such as I alluded to earlier.

I am pleased to see here the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) and I would be happy to provide him with that submission, when it comes across my desk, for an alternative funding proposal for the family farm. The banks have relocated to the cities to play the money screens and look after the speculative big end of town.

Let us not be fooled by the removal of the farm household support. It does not mean things are getting any better on the land, for all the reasons I, and my farming friend, detailed in that letter. The primary industry budget statements blandly credit the dropping of this scheme to the reduction in demand for its support. In 1994, as I pointed out, there were 284 recipients; at last count there were 47. I will bet there has been no other research done on where those other 237 families are now. I suspect they are not ploughing along happily on the farm after the lifeline this scheme offered. I bet they are gone from farming.

Unless we do something to create an alternative to the banks to finance the family farm, there will be no reason to introduce ever again a farm household support scheme like this, because there will be no farm households to support. Corporate farms will have taken over and, irony among ironies, not only will they be funded by the banks—many of them foreign owned—but they will be owned by the banks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Thank you to all members who have contributed to the debate. I gather it has been wide‐ranging. The farm household support scheme has generally been acknowledged to be a failure. Farmers will not go on it because of what they see as the onerous requirements for repayment and so forth. The government has taken the view that it is more effective to look at welfare arrangements and the impact on farmers of such things as the assets test. We now have, as I think has been alluded to during the debate by various people here this morning, a report available to us on options, and the government will be considering that in due course.

SPEECH.PARA: I was interested in the comments of the honourable member for Calare (Mr Andren), those that I caught, and I would like to make a couple of brief remarks. Firstly, there is always concern that corporate farming will take over in Australia. However, historically, the ownership of Australia's farms has remained between 90 per cent and 93 per cent family based. Since the early days of colonisation, through all of the ups and down—the Great Depression, the 1890s, which were as tough, if not tougher, as current times, and the 1930s, which were desperation times—the figures have fluctuated by only two or three percentage points. Family farm ownership has never really slipped below 90 per cent, and that is essentially because it is such an efficient economic unit.

I agree that, in broad terms, we need to look to alternative sources of financing for the family farm. At the moment, it is largely debt financed and it may be that more innovative approaches are needed for the future. Farmers complain, and understandably, about the interest rates that the banks impose upon them. As a government we are intent upon saying to the banks and the financial sector in this country that we are showing long‐term support for agriculture. We are developing a business plan, and a set of policies and strategies derived from that, to maximise the chances of the family farm and we expect the banks to do the same.

Let us get away from the problem of excessive interest rates. It is worth noting here that evidence submitted to the rural assistance scheme inquiry, which we have set up, suggests very strongly—the inquiry is only at a preliminary stage at this juncture and I certainly do not want to pre‐empt any of the work that it may put together—that there is no evidence of market failure in the provision of capital to the rural sector.

Let me comment very briefly on what is happening to those farmers who do leave the land, an issue that was also touched on by the honourable member for Calare. I, too, have an interest and a concern about that matter. We will do a bit of research on it. One of our rural councillors who has dealt with this problem extensively has followed through on it and undertaken a bit of study of his own. Interestingly enough, he discovered that many of the farmers who left the land found that the time leading up to leaving the farm was the most difficult of all. I suspect that any person in this country who has seen the failure of his or her private enterprise would be able to relate to the dreadfully stressful times leading up to the collapse. It is a situation that can never be fun.

However, when farmers did leave, they were able to begin their lives again and, almost universally, they expressed surprise that they were able to get a job quite easily. Farmers are more highly skilled than they often recognise. That is not to say that I resile, in any way, from the need for us to do everything we can to ensure that as many farmers as possible can secure their future. But having said that, I will very briefly refer to the Farm Household Support Amendment Bill 1996. The effect of the bill will be to prevent people who are not entitled to receive farm household support payments on the cut‐off date, that is 28 days after the bill receives royal assent, from obtaining farm household support at any time in the future.

For those people who are entitled to receive farm household support payments on the cut‐off date, transitional provisions will permit them to continue to receive the support until such time as they are no longer eligible. Permitting continued access to the farm household support payments will require that the access be unbroken and once a person becomes ineligible to receive farm household support payments, that person cannot be paid farm household support payments at a later date.

The bill retains the operation of other provisions of the farm household support scheme for those people who will continue to receive farm household support payments after the cut‐off date and FHS payments will still be made as a loan which may be converted to a grant under certain circumstances.

I should emphasise that the operation of the drought relief payment, the DRP, administered under the Farm Household Support Act 1992, is unchanged by the termination of the farm household support scheme in all but one regard. Those former farm household support recipients, who have transferred to the DRP, will not be able to transfer back to the farm household support scheme after the cut‐off date when their drought relief recovery period finishes.

I think the previous speaker had something to say about that recovery period. We have extended it from six months to 12 months, a very significant movement in terms of the assistance that we offer to the farm sector. In fact, in broad, it has resulted in an increase of something like $170 million over that provided by the previous administration in the forward estimates for drought relief, thus reflecting our very real commitment to this sector. That $170 million, I must say, pales into some insignificance against the value of the interest rate cuts that sound economic management has and will continue to deliver. Presuming that it is properly passed on by the banks, and my evidence is that they are claiming that it is being passed on to the farm sector, that is around $300 million per annum relief already provided by the three reductions in interest rates that we have seen since coming to government just under 12 months ago.

In conclusion may I say that we announced the termination of the farm household support scheme in the 1996‐97 budget. We are considering the most appropriate way forward in terms of meeting the needs of destitute farm families in the most appalling circumstances. At the same time we are considering the best way forward in terms of ensuring that as many as possible of those farmers that are finding it difficult are moved into a new era when they are able to join the 20 per cent of Australian farmers who are, at the moment, reaping very real financial rewards for their efforts in terms of return on capital. We want as many as possible who are not in that bracket to be assisted into it and that is what we are aiming to do. Thank you.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 December 1996, on motion by Mr Anderson:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe, Neil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As we have indicated in respect of this legislation, the opposition is comfortable with what is proposed in this legislation. Most of it is tidying up and slowly progressing forward. We understand there has been wide industry consultation. We certainly have not received any expressions of concern and so in those circumstances we are quite comfortable to support this bill without dissent.

SPEECH.PARA: On a couple of the items though, I would like to just make some passing comment to indicate the way some of our own thinking is evolving for those who conscientiously read or listen to these debates.

There may be some confusion in the minds of studious observers of these proceedings when they find that there is more about the Farm Household Support Act involved in this particular legislation, as well—we did not clean it all up with the last bit. I gather that there are some provisions that continue to operate while the other legislation still does. These provisions are meant, primarily, to prevent double dipping which may occur when people are able to take up benefits under drought relief schemes and under broader opportunities that are available in social security and veterans' affairs legislation when it all conjuncts with the FHSA.

This just shows the eternal dilemma we have. As I mentioned in the earlier debate, I remember when we introduced the farm household support scheme and the then Prime Minister's country task force spent a long time with the primary industries minister—who, at the time, was Simon Crean, I think—and the social security minister, who was probably Brian Howe. We worked through these things, introducing the legislation at 4 a.m., going home from that session only to face yet another barrage of discontent from rural constituents about the way they were treated by Labor and all this sort of stuff when we had been there until 4 o'clock in the morning introducing this sort of legislation.

Now we find double dipping, so the dog is always chasing its tail around in a circle. It does not mean that we do not continue to try to provide fairly for people who are in difficult financial situations, but where there is a loophole—Garfield Barwick set the path a long time ago—the conservative approach is to find it and slip down through it. So, inevitably, we find ourselves here in the parliament trying to close the loopholes as quickly as we open them. I have no doubt that the same thing will continue, but let us hope that it moderates over time.

This legislation also makes provision to extend until 30 June the provisions for the Wool Council to maintain its funding for research and promotion. An interesting situation evolving, particularly in the promotion and future use of wool is the changing marketplace for wool, and many of us have been involved in this dilemma for many years. Last night I had the pleasure of dining with a number of representatives from the textile industry, particularly in Victoria, and they were making the suggestion that it is time for the wool industry to seriously consider abandoning its longstanding promotion and logo of 100 per cent pure wool.

They said that the market no longer regards a pure wool garment as a pragmatic garment. People are in a hurry; they want easy to clean, easy to hang, easy to press and easy to wear garments. The properties of wool change when they have some synthetic, or other natural fibres added, such as cotton. Even with just small additives, the properties of wool change, according to these people, so that it is suddenly a very attractive product. The marketing of pure wool and the insistence on pure wool products may, in fact, be holding back opportunities for wool.

I am not saying that I know these things, but I am just throwing into the discussion the fact that leaders in the textile industry, who are aware of the longstanding interest in wool and the marketability of wool, are saying that the industry itself, and the wool promotion council, need to start thinking about repositioning this strategy, particularly as it has been around for a long time and a lot of money has been invested.

Yesterday afternoon in the fashion parade, as it has been called, that was put on in the House by the textile industry, we saw one extremely positive development; that is, the invention, if you can call it that, and the development—with R&D in the industry here in Australia—of a new denim yarn which is a cotton‐wool mix. The industry is quite confident that its properties and attractiveness may take the international denim market by storm.
