If that is to be the case, then that would be a fabulous injection for both the cotton and wool‐growing industries in Australia.

I make those preliminary comments because this is not a new debate. But it is one that I very strongly call on my conservative opponents opposite, those in government now, to seriously think about. In January, in a very public statement, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) made the comment, published in the Australian, that he and the government see Australia's future in this area of commodities and products being to ensure that we improve the quality of the raw material, or the raw product, rather than focusing, as we have been talking about and trying to do for some years now, on value adding.

This is not a new thought among the conservatives. It was first presented to me by the now Minister for Defence, Ian McLachlan, when he was President of the National Farmers Federation. He put quite strongly to us as members of the country task force—I think the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) who is here at the table was present at that very meeting—that it was not in the interests of primary producers in Australia to support the development of value adding because they had very well‐established markets for their bulk exports—bales of wool, shiploads of wheat or whatever—and that exposing those products to the vagaries of value adding in manufacturing in Australia was not the way to go.

Many of us would be flabbergasted to think that anyone in Australia could even think that way. But I make it very clear to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that it was not a new thought expressed by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in January, that it is actually a well‐argued and articulated hypothesis that has been around amongst the conservatives in agriculture and minerals for many years, and it is being argued actively again.

So here we have the wool industry struggling with its strategy of exporting bales of wool—and I can remember my colleague who is in the chamber tonight giving his views many times on the so‐called export of experts who were in charge of that over the years—but now we have the textile industry saying to us that there are some new and innovative ways to go about doing this. They are suggesting that in fact value adding in Australia holds some real potential at the very time when the people in government who are now running the industry are saying that this is not the way they are interested in going.

I call for a rethink on that, and I suggest that people particularly listen to those in the textile industry, although we know that they are not always constructive in these debates. Many of their concerns about tariff reductions, for instance, are totally contrary to the view. In an article in January I saw that the Wool Council was calling for a rapid reduction in tariffs in Australia so that they will get better opportunities to sell their raw product overseas.

Our overseas customer is saying to us, `If you reduce your tariff barriers to our products, then we will take more of your raw materials.' That is all very well. What happens when you have the Wool Council coming out and calling for accelerated tariff reductions is that the textile industry suddenly says, `Hey, don't you care about us? Don't you care about the jobs? Don't you care about what we are trying to do with your product to give it a future?' The answer, on that evidence, is no. So this is not an insignificant debate.

We are, in this legislation, just passing a bit of machinery that enables the funding to continue. We understand that the Wool Council is developing its further strategy for post 30 June 1997. What I am saying to the Wool Council is: do not be led by Minister Anderson's hypothesis that we are better off concentrating on the development of the raw material and walking away from attempting to value add in this country. Our farm producers—and the nation as a whole—have a far better future by taking the view of the textile manufacturers, the people who want to expand their businesses, based on improving, developing and expanding the use of the products.

A very interesting discussion and debate will unfold on this issue. And I signal here that we are quite incensed that a government could actually begin the process of walking away from value adding in this economy when so much effort has been put in by so many people in the last 10 or 15 years to try and get an export culture, a productivity culture, a research and development culture and a value adding culture established right across the nation. The proof of the pudding is in the eating: the dramatic increase in manufactured exports in the Australian economy, as against the decline in commodity exports in dollar value—even though volumes have gone up, dollar values have gone down. The contrast is stark and real. It beggars belief that anybody could conclude that it is in the national interest to go any other way. But that is unfolding and it is something that I am quite confident will become part of a significant debate in the nation during the next few years.

We are supporting this legislation and approve of it. But I have taken this opportunity to make a few comments to set the parameters of what we see as a very significant debate emerging in our economy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) for supporting this series of amendments to clean up various defects in acts and to make sure that we do not revisit ground we have gone over in other areas. I will refer later to his comments on the textile industry, but I will first speak in support of the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996 and, in particular, the first amendment to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemical Code Act 1994.

SPEECH.PARA: Compensation provisions already apply to agricultural and veterinary chemical products, but do not extend to an individual active constituent where this active constituent is the responsibility of a company separate from the chemical product company. This situation relates to the active constituent review information requested by the National Registration Authority for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals for the purpose of reviewing existing active constituents to ensure they meet contemporary standards.

In a nutshell, this amendment seeks to ensure that compensation provisions apply to all active constituents in use by chemical product companies, as they do to the agricultural and veterinary chemical products. The amendment will remove the concern about commercial exploitation by providing compensation provisions equivalent to those already applying to agricultural and veterinary chemical products, and will ensure commonality in the entire process of review.

In addition, the proposed amendment will facilitate the generation of information for the review program by including the active constituents of existing chemical products. This amendment is all about a commonsense approach by a commonsense government and seeks to provide greater protection for those in the chemical production industry.

Another part of this bill amends the Farm Household Support Act 1992, which was very well summed up by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) at the close of the debate on that individual act but is referred to in the tidy‐up session in this legislation. Quite simply, due to the complexity of the various financial aids available to those in primary industry, this amendment seeks to ensure that recipients of financial assistance cannot double‐dip when receiving drought relief payments.

Currently, when drought relief payments are calculated an amount is allowed for a partner. Should this partner subsequently claim social security—in other words, family allowance or parenting allowance—this person would receive the same support twice. That would be once as a component under drought relief payments and again under social security benefits. Ultimately, though, such a situation leads to a gross overpayment, resulting in even further financial hardship when restitution is to be made. This amendment will remove the possibility of that occurring.

We only need to think about farmers out there doing it a bit tough when the weather has not gone the way that they want or situations are not as good as they could be, to remember that for generations farms were owned outright by families, whereas the farms have now been broken up and sold off. Indeed, over generations these farms have got mortgages on them, some so big the farmers cannot climb over them. But still these people, the very backbone of Australia's rural society, hang in there and keep working.

The days of this country riding on the sheep's back, I believe, are gone, and we need to get smarter in our farming applications. We do need to pursue such things as the supermarket to Asia approach. When times get tough and these very proud people put out their hand, they are not used to filling in government forms for assistance. Sometimes by mistake they fill in two sets of forms to seek aid through income support.

It is a shock. I have had one of these people come in to me, and when I spoke to that person I realised from the outset that it had been a very big hurdle to cross, to actually go and seek assistance. Some have said that for the first time in their life they have actually had to go and put their hand out, and it goes a long way towards breaking the back. We have seen so many farmers walk away from the farm these days. We can remember, through the heavy periods of the drought and the periods of very high interest rates under the former government, the people walking away from the farms, the marriage breakdowns and, sadly, the suicides. To lose the farm is one thing, but to lose life over it is another dimension altogether.

Removing either temptation or an error that may occur by double‐dipping, and making sure that once support is in place there is no need for people to pay back money to the government because they have only been paid what they are properly due, will reduce a lot of stress on these people.

This bill addresses also the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Act 1993. As the member for Burke said, in the chamber we have the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), who has spoken many times and well. Even before my time in this chamber I used to listen to the debates over the radio and heard him speak out on the wool industry, along with Wilson Tuckey, who has been a great defender of the wool industry in Western Australia.

This amendment seeks to extend the sunset date from 30 June 1997 to June 2000 for wool industry contributions to the Australian Animal Health Council. The objective of this amendment is to ensure the provision of an interim funding arrangement pending wool industry agreement on longer term funding.

The Australian Animal Health Council was established on 19 January 1996 and is funded by contributions by various animal industries. The predecessor program was the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council, which was also funded by the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation.

The Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Act was amended back in 1996 to provide for wool industry contributions to the Australian Animal Health Council to be funded by the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation until 30 June 1997. It is obvious that an extension of this funding arrangement is required to enable the wool industry to continue to meet its financial obligations to the Australian Animal Health Corporation and to examine options to provide for a longer term solution. I understand that the Wool Council of Australia supports these amendments.

I refer to the comments that the member for Burke made about the textile industry. We have a great textile industry in my electorate—indeed, we have National Textiles based at Rutherford. Unfortunately, they have just had to downsize and lay off another 20 staff to restructure and remain competitive. I am glad to see them talk about developments in fabrics with the inclusion of wool and cotton together to produce fabrics that will work in Australia, because we can blend those and work those up at Rutherford and produce fabric in Australia.

One of the crying shames is that, over generations, not just in the last government but through many governments, we have seen a deterioration of wool product being spun and made into cloth in Australia. Indeed, now to buy some of the best wool in Australia, the microfines that are produced in Australia, one has to buy fabric woven and spun either in England, Italy, France or Belgium. That is a sad shame because it is a very labour intensive industry even though there are high levels of mechanisation. Perhaps it was the high tariffs that kept the industry uncompetitive for a long period of time and then, when the crunch came, they were no longer able to compete. I know the people at National Textiles are investing millions of dollars to make sure that their plight is not the same, that they do keep up with technology and that they do remain competitive.

As I said, the lack of availability of quality cloth has led to a lot of problems. Indeed, the suit I wear today is Australian wool blended with mohair and made by a tailor in Newcastle, a clothing company called Rundles, which faces the possibility of closure—it is under administration at the moment. It is a shame because their history in Newcastle goes back, I understand, well over 100 years. To hear people like the member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) get up last night and put the blame for this on the current government, I find rather ludicrous. Simply, the former government was one of the major instruments in bringing down the tariffs, its archaic industrial relations laws allowing for this company to have to wind back to compete, to overextend and then no longer be able to compete in the Australian market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps you should talk about the fall in retail sales.
—The fall in retail sales, I will talk about that—
—No, you won't, you will keep on the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill.

—Thank you, I am glad you reminded me of that because I am discussing the part which covers the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Act and, Mr Deputy Speaker, with all due respect, it is partly about promotions and organisation and the use of the textile. The demand for the textile has dropped off because of the very high interest rates which we saw climb during the term of the previous government. We then saw a recession, a recession that we had to have, and this recession that we had to have was one of the major factors there. We just heard the member opposite talk about the drop in retail sales: there are direct links and effects. There is no way that the previous government can walk away from the fact that it was there for 13 years, that it administered the policies in those 13 years. We have come in in the last 12 months—or 12 months in a couple of weeks time—and we are trying to clean up and fix their mistakes. As we heard our Treasurer (Mr Costello) say in the House, interest rates now are at the lowest ever stage.

SPEECH.PARA: Going back to the wool bill, which I am sure you were about to remind me of, Mr Deputy Speaker, it makes the clothing more affordable. When interest rates are down, and the mortgage repayments are down, the affordability of the loan puts more cash back into the pockets. I include the $34 a week family tax benefit that came in this year and I am hoping that people therefore will go out and invest that money in new clothing, particularly with Rundles in Newcastle, so that we can see this company survive. It is a great company and has probably some of the best tailors in Australia when it comes to making fine quality clothing.

Further, the act goes through and repeals and introduces many savings provisions. One there is the Tobacco Marketing Act 1965. The repeal of this act allows the Australian tobacco industry to participate fully in the international markets. The Tobacco Marketing Act 1965 provided the legislative basis for the Australian Tobacco Marketing Advisory Committee, which cased to operate on 3 July 1995. It was agreed by the industry that all rights, assets, obligations and liabilities be transferred to the Tobacco Research and Development Corporation, in anticipation of the repeal of this act.

The act also goes through and frees up minor amendments in the Dried Vine Fruits Equalisation Act 1978 and brings things up to date in the Forestry and Timber Bureau Act 1930 by removing Papua New Guinea as being a territory of Australia, which has been there for many years. I think it goes back to 1975 and the independence of New Guinea.

This is a series of minor amendments that are proposed to the above acts to facilitate the correction of formal errors, omit redundancies and fix misdescribed statements. As I said, I am glad that the opposition supports this act and I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I must confess that I came in to the chamber to address a few caustic words about the next bill. I find myself ahead of myself, so as a compromise measure, I would like to go back to the previous bill, with your indulgence, Mr Deputy Speaker. I want to draw attention to something that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) said which is very germane to the bill we are now discussing.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister was talking about family farm ownership. He was pontificating, as he is wont to do, and said that the level of family farm ownership in Australia was very high, and in fact over 90 per cent. What the minister does not realise is that multinationals today do not want the land. The land is an encumbrance. It is something they cannot move quickly. But the multinationals control the product so they have family farmers in total thraldom to them. It is real bondage because any slight movement in the price is felt immediately by the farmer. Of course this affects vegetable growing, the chicken industry and beef.

In the 1920s when `Red Ted' Theodore set up the establishment of publicly owned abattoirs in Queensland, he did not do it for those abattoirs to make a profit; he did it to break the monopoly of the foreign ownership at the time. In those days, it was Vesteys. There was no doubt that the cattle industry in Australia was in total thraldom to Vesteys interest and Theodore's strategy was to provide an alternative source of processing.

I ask this House: what difference is there between the position that Vesteys held then and the position held by Japanese and American processors today? Quite clearly we need an alternative form of processing so that markets can be addressed through other than the oligopoly that we have now. I do not subscribe in this day to state ownership, but I do believe that, if we really care about agriculture, we ought to be looking at funding a grower organisation to establish abattoirs to break the vertical integration of that foreign ownership. In my view Minister Anderson does not really understand the rural sector. He speaks from a silver spoon‐fed background and that is a great pity.

I am reminded of the early days of the wool crisis when the previous government initiated the Garnaut report. Garnaut is a man for whom I hold the utmost contempt. He is greatly overstated and his report Australia and the Northeast Asian ascendancy has done enormous damage to Australia because it was swallowed hook, line and sinker by politicians on both sides. I went to Dubbo to give my views to the industry on the Garnaut report, which I thought was a very suspect document. Young Mr Anderson, the minister, got up and read chapter after chapter from the Garnaut report, which was understandably quite flattering about itself. When we broke for morning tea, one of the local National Party people said to me, `My word. We are so lucky to have a bright young man like John Anderson.' I remember saying to him, `I think you are about to get the government you deserve,' and that is a pity.

Now the member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) mentioned the Wool Council, and I have been very critical of wool marketing arrangements in Australia. The truth is that the Wool Council, the round table and Minister Anderson are as one. There is no doubt that we have to look very hard at wool marketing. I do not think it is so much a matter of value adding as one of making sure that wool growers hold on to their product until further down the production scale. It has been shown in other parts of the world—in America, for instance—that, where cooperative organisations have enabled growers to hold on to their product and to sell the value‐added product and get the benefit themselves for value adding, they have done very much better. I believe we need to be setting up mechanisms where the Australian wool grower can hold the interest in his wool down to, at least, the single yarn stage.

The member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin) talked about Australia no longer riding on the sheep's back. It is true; it does not. But this should be recognised: if we were to process wool to the top making stage—and we are the world's best top makers; we have actually eclipsed the French in our productivity—wool would today be our biggest single export. Wool is important, because wool is the single most important small business in Australia, and it is so widely spread that it has an impact on much of rural Australia. That is something that needs to be looked at. I do not believe that, with the present wool marketing arrangements, the Wool Council or any of the major companies are going to seriously consider this. It is going to be an initiative that must come from wool growers, and it is an initiative that will only succeed if it is looked on sympathetically by government.

In terms of processing wool, I believe that a player that has been overlooked in the market is India. India has re‐equipped itself with the world's best machinery, and I think there would be a good synergy from using Australian produced top making for processing into yarn in India. I favour India over China because India has actually beaten the Chinese in the process of equipping itself with the best equipment, English is generally understood in India, and the legal system sort of works, which is more than really can be said for the situation in China.

I have no real problem with the bill, as it is basically the machinery for the arrangements, except to say that we have to do something constructive about the wool industry. The innovations happening now are coming from individual wool growers. I see nothing of substance coming from Wool International, which is currently seeking its own survival by trying to join forces with the two other big players in the industry, Elders and Dalgety‐Wesfarmers. I believe that it is the work of individuals in the industry that is doing most to benefit industry.

The member for Burke talked about the value of the processors. I believe that it is the wool users who should be the people most involved in the merchandising and advertising of wool. When you look at the history of Australia's wool marketing, it has been abysmal. We have spent $2 billion trying to increase wool consumption in the United States, with negligible effect. I recall that, when I finished wool classing, our instructor said to us, `Everyone of you will now go up and class a clip'—which every one of us did. He then went on to say, `Unless you can increase consumption per capita in the United States, wool doesn't have a good long‐term future.' We spent $2 billion trying to increase that consumption, without success. That was $2 billion of wool growers' money that was basically wasted. I believe that there are marketeers in the world who could have had much greater success than that.

Indeed, one of the famous Italian manufacturers of fine wools and material sent Mr Todhunter to America to market their product, on the basis that he had a month and then he had to support himself. He did it very well and that American market is now a substantial part of the company's export business. So it is quite clear that we were capable of doing it, but it certainly was not done by the ways and methods of the Wool Corporation. I do not believe that the organisation we have now, which consists basically of the same people that sit around the minister's round table, has any better grasp of what is needed.

Certainly, the member for Burke is right: the processors need to be listened to. Wool‐cotton is a very good blend. It has a big future in denim. It is certainly going to improve the material. I believe there is a market also for wool‐hemp and wool‐linen, but why do we not address the crying need for wool‐polyester? I was at a Kangaroo exercise in the north when our servicemen complained bitterly about the polyester clothes they were supplied with and how they simply did not work in the tropics. You could see by the condition the soldiers were in, in those polyester shirts, that there was a need for a better material. I believe that nothing is too good for our services; we should have the very best cloth. Any shirt for the tropics would be enhanced by the inclusion of wool in the mixture.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank those who have participated in the debate on the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996. In particular, I acknowledge the genuine interest of the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) in these industries and his commitment to the people in them. Even if I think he is a bit skew‐whiff in some ways in terms of policy prescriptions, I thank him for his contribution and would like to make a few comments about some of the things he said.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, he is right when he says that India offers some real future for wool exporting opportunities in this country. The great problem there, particularly vis‐a‐vis China, is that India maintains very high rates of tariffs, particularly against tops. The Indians do so for two reasons. In general, they maintain high levels of tariffs as a revenue raising measure on wool because they regard it as a luxury. I think the tariff on tops is about double what it is for greasy wool, and the reason for that is that they have an extensive top making industry themselves, to which the previous speaker alluded.

As it happens, I spent a considerable amount of time just yesterday with the Indian minister for textiles. The activities covered by his portfolio, textiles in India, incidentally, support no fewer than 60 million Indians. That is quite mind‐boggling. We worked through this issue at great length and I left him in no doubt that Australia's position on this is that we are all in favour of joint ventures, all in favour of expanding the trade; that we want to cooperate and strengthen ties with India, particularly in relation to the wool industry and the activities related to that; but that we feel very strongly that the lowering of tariffs is very much in their interests.

Perhaps there are some lessons to be learnt even from the model whereby Australia is now exporting wool tops to Mexico. They are allowed into that country with no tariff barriers being imposed at all, they are then value added by the Mexicans and re‐exported, under NAFTA, tariff free to the United States. It is a happy arrangement which works very well for Australia, works very well for Mexico and works very well, we hope, for the Americans and their consumers. It is seeing Mexican consumption of Australian wool rise very rapidly—whilst admittedly off a low base—by no less than 60 per cent last year.

If that sort of growth continues and if we see the sorts of projections that are now shaping up for India following through, then we will indeed be looking at a much brighter future for wool. I must say that it is not before time. With the knowledge that nine out of 10 woolgrowers this year will lose money and that most of them have now lost money for the sixth year running, there is no doubt at all about the seriousness of the situation.

We have at least, through the round table process somewhat disparagingly referred to by the previous speaker, managed to establish that the industry can work together. I regard it as an absolute prerequisite for recovery that the industry works together in a unified way and recognises that the enemies for the wool industry and for woolgrowers are not other sectors of the same industry but the alternative fibres.

They really have to capture market share again, and that is not going to be easy. In their heartland markets, in terms of traditional outlets such as Europe, the research shows that an interesting phenomena amongst consumers of almost all goods is now affecting wool; that is, increasingly people expect real value for money from mid‐range commodities, whether it is motor cars, electronics or clothing. They actually expect qualities of them now that 30 years ago they would have only expected to find in the goods that were priced two, three and four times as much. As a result of that, they are increasingly reluctant to pay big premiums for what are regarded as very narrow increments in quality and prestige. So we do have a problem.

The name of the game for the wool industry is promotion, promotion, promotion. We have to expand demand for the product and, notwithstanding my general agreement with the comments about the apparent lack of result from the vast amounts of money that have been spent on promotion in recent years, I do think that we are now looking at a much leaner and meaner operation, and certainly on vastly reduced budgets in terms of the generic promotion of wool in the late 1990s. We are going to have to make sure that strategies are effective. This government believes that whilst we have a vital role to play in market research and development and in market access issues and those sorts of things, the industry itself has to by and large take a lead. The people with the greatest vested interest in the industry are those who have the greatest capacity to really make it work in the future.

May I comment very briefly just on Wool International to reassure the previous speaker and anybody else who is interested that they will not be buying themselves a future? It is quite widely recognised that it is the government's view that, as the stockpile is dealt with and as various other charges imposed upon that body by the 1993 act are discharged, the body will be increasingly wound down and in due course will fade from the scene altogether. We do have a lot of bodies in the wool industry and some rationalisation is, I think, generally agreed to be a very healthy objective.

Coming to the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1996 which is before us, I will be as brief as I can. Firstly, the proposed amendments to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Code of 1994 will extend the part 3 compensation provisions to cover the active constituent of a chemical product, as distinct from only applying to an agricultural or veterinary chemical product as is currently the case. The active constituent compensation provisions will apply between the primary applicant with a protected active constituent and a secondary applicant seeking access to certain information relating to the protected active constituent.

In particular, the proposed amendments are in response to concerns expressed by some companies involved with the marketing of active constituents. These concerns especially relate to the provision of active constituent review information requested by the National Registration Authority for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals, the NRA. The review information is for the purpose of the NRA reviewing existing and especially old active constituents to ensure that they meet contemporary public health, occupational health and safety, environmental impact and trade standards.

Coming again to farm household support, the act of 1992 will be amended. Those amendments will strengthen the multiple entitlement exclusion provisions of the Farm Household Support Act in relation to the drought relief payment. The current multiple entitlement exclusion provisions in the Farm Household Support Act need to be strengthened to restrict the level of income support payments to a DRP recipient or their partner through either the Social Security Act 1991, the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 or the Farm Household Support Act to the equivalent level of entitlements received under other Commonwealth income support measures.

The proposed amendments will prevent recipients of the DRP or their partners double dipping by receiving support in the form of a couple‐rate payment under this act while at the same time obtaining payments or allowances identified separately under the Social Security Act 1991 or the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. When DRP is calculated, an amount for the partner is included in the DRP payment. Hence, if the partner were to claim a payment in their own right such as a partner allowance or parenting allowance, they would in effect receive the same support twice—once as a component of the drought relief payment and again as a separate payment under the Social Security Act 1991 or the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986. Following this amendment such a case will not be possible.

There are in excess of 1,450 recipients of DRP, or their spouses, who are also claiming social security income support payments in addition to receiving the DRP. Based on these figures, the estimated saving from the proposal to strengthen the multiple entitlement exclusion provisions would be a little over $7 million per year. I know that some of those members opposite will understand entirely what I mean when I say that, in this day and age, when one has to be very careful with budgetary outlays and when we all accept the need to ensure that targeting of assistance is effectively undertaken and followed through, the issues can become awesomely complex. This is an outstanding example of just how tricky it can be to get these things right. Nonetheless, we think this will remove a small anomaly under which some people were enjoying a little more than their fair share of the cake.

As part of the December 1994 tobacco restructuring package, the activities of the Australian Tobacco Marketing Advisory Committee—or ATMAC, as it was known—were wound up on 3 July 1995 in anticipation of the repeal of the Tobacco Marketing Act 1965, under which ATMAC operated. Schedule 3 of the proposed legislation repeals the act and provides for the transfer of all rights, assets, obligations and liabilities from ATMAC to the Tobacco Research and Development Corporation. This is a troubled Australian industry, but tobacco farmers are doing their best to grapple with their future. They are operating at the moment under a restructuring package, which will see many farmers identify other futures for themselves.

I would like to make the general comment that I have the utmost sympathy for tobacco farmers. We live in an age when everybody wants to slate people who smoke, everybody is after the manufacturers and there is a great deal of community angst over it. The poor old tobacco farmer is often absolutely the meat in the sandwich in all of this. Many of them are people who, at various times, have been encouraged by governments of all persuasions to go out there and farm tobacco. In fact, I think I am right in saying that they were a protected industry during the Second World War. They were regarded as so important in terms of the product they produced for our service men and women fighting abroad, and so forth, that it was a protected industry to make sure the produce was available.

In this day and age, a very different view is taken of the desirability of providing cigarettes for anybody. But we must remember the need to work with tobacco farmers, who in many ways are victims of past government policy. In this age when we want to get everybody out of that industry we need to work with those farmers so that they can restructure and find their way forward.

In relation to the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Act 1993, the previous speaker, the member for Kalgoorlie, had quite a bit to say about the wool industry. I will confine myself to a few remarks, having responded more broadly to his comments. The amendment to the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Act 1993 will extend the sunset date to 30 June 2000 for wool industry contributions to the Australian Animal Health Council—the AAHC—from 30 June 1997, when the current funding arrangements expire. The objective of this provision and the reason for its sunset is to provide an interim funding arrangement pending wool industry agreement on longer‐term funding. The extension of the sunset date to 30 June 2000 will enable the wool industry to continue to meet their financial obligations to fund the AAHC while they examine options to provide for a longer‐term solution for funding the AAHC. I commend the amendments to the Main Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 December 1996, on motion by Mr Miles:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency Bill 1996 proposes to appropriate funds and to issue the securities to effect Australia's membership of the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency, MIGA. The purpose of MIGA, which is an institution of the World Bank, is to foster foreign investment in developing countries by providing insurance against various risks and advisory services concerning foreign investment. Membership should assist Australian firms doing business: for example, through obtaining a MIGA guarantee or through obtaining political risk insurance. In addition, Australian membership should be viewed positively by other nations in terms of fulfilling our international development obligations.

SPEECH.PARA: The total cost of the shares in MIGA is around $25 million, of which 10 per cent will be paid in cash in 1996-97, a further 10 per cent by way of a note of promise, and the balance being a contingent liability which is on call if required. In 1993, the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade concluded that the benefits of joining MIGA were in excess of the costs and that therefore Australia should join. The Australian Labor Party supported that recommendation at the time and now, in opposition, we are pleased to support the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to briefly comment on the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency Bill 1996. As has been outlined, it is an institution of the World Bank. I am on the public record as always being a bit of a sceptic as far as some of these international financial institutions are concerned. But it is my understanding that the insurance that is afforded to Australian companies investing in other countries, through Australia's membership of this agency, is well worth Australia belonging to it.

SPEECH.PARA: I know there are a number of other issues involved as far as MIGA is concerned. As set out in the EM, MIGA's purpose is to foster foreign investment in developing countries. I imagine that the speaker who is to follow me will express some concerns about the encouragement of Australian institutions and companies investing in developing countries. I have had it brought to my attention that some Australian mining companies are investing and exploring in countries that we might think are a bit politically unstable. However, Australia's membership of MIGA affords these companies insurance against the risks of currency transfer, ex‐appropriation, war and civil disturbance. Membership should be encouraged because it gives Australian companies the opportunity to invest abroad with security.

We live in a world that economically and industrially is getting smaller. We are continually faced with concerns for our own constituencies with regard to foreign investment in Australia. But, by the same token, Australian companies are being very proactive in investing in other parts of the world and, again, I instance mining industries. To a certain extent, I remain a bit sceptical about World Bank type financial institutions but my understanding of the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency, and the insurance that it provides to Australian companies investing overseas, is that it is well worth Australia's membership. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous member said he remained a little sceptical and I think he should. The Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency Bill 1996 is just another grab at this great straw of internationalism, which has been a hallmark of this and previous governments in Australia. We are told that the analysis says that there will be more benefit than cost. I think that analysis is very dubious and, in any case, it is going to be marginal.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it amusing that we spend so much time on these multilateral bodies. Here is another that is going to be dominated by the United States. It is quite clear from the capital structure that that will be the case. There is no provision in these insurance contingencies for devaluation of currency, which is one of the very big risks taken in investment.

We are going to all this trouble to set up an organisation that will, in the main, be used by large business—and mainly by foreign business. It will not be used much by small Australian businesses. We do not give anything like the same support to industry in our own country. The Development Bank has basically ceased to exist. As a branch of the now privatised Commonwealth Bank, its charter is invalid. Its charter would be ultra vires a companies act. It is necessary to re‐establish that sort of facility in Australia if we are going to do something serious.

The previous speaker mentioned the growth of the manufacturing industry. This myth has to be countered. We are told that manufacturing now represents a growing percentage of our exports. That is true, but what is not realised is that importation of exactly the same sorts of things has increased at the same rate off a bigger base. So the situation is getting worse, not better. We are going to have no jobs in this country if we do not address the urgent need for an Australian import replacement manufacturing industry.

I do not intend to dwell long on this bill. I certainly do not intend to oppose it. It is just another example of the fetish drafts by successive governments in this country. I made the point in the House the other day that in Australia we are fast approaching a one‐party system where both major parties have identical policies and only quibble at the margins. This bill will do very little for Australia. It is a bill, which, over time, will provide a few lofty jobs for a few people, but it will be of no great benefit to industry.

There was some criticism of the member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) in this House. I think it was a little unfair. I have spoken to Ian McLachlan on occasions. I think Ian McLachlan and the government are aware of the great benefit of bilateral trade arrangements and would pursue those. I believe that Ian McLachlan will do more than any previous minister has done in his capacity as Minister for Defence to make sure there is a real Australian component there. The member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) misrepresented, to some degree, the views of the member. The member is a man whose views should be listened to much more in the cabinet. I believe he is isolated in the government. Having made those few remarks, I am satisfied.

Mr MILES (Braddon—Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister) (12.54 p.m.)—in reply—I recognise people's contributions here today. There has been a level of scepticism about being involved in multilateral agreements, but we live in a world community, a global community, and I think everybody recognises that the boundaries are disappearing and distances are shrinking because of the capacity for the world society to work together and because of developments in transport and communication systems. We are closer together as people. We all are aware of a degree of sharing and working with each other.

History is dotted with the difficulties of doing that but, as an Australian government at this stage in history, we believe that we have a role to play in the global community and in working through the structures of the world community. As some of the speakers have indicated, there is a degree of scepticism. That will always be the case, probably right throughout the world. In any country there will be people who are sceptical of centralised bureaucracies and structures which, generally speaking, they have very little control over or say in, even in a democratic sense.

Yet governments of every country, as they participate in this global community of ours, have a responsibility to make judgments, assessments and decisions as to where they can best link in as participants in a world community while, at the same time, giving consideration to the interests of their own people, their own society and their own communities. I believe that in this regard the government has found that balance.

Of course, this proposal for the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency Bill 1996 is one which was supported by the previous government. It has been taken up by us and we support it as a coalition government. It is beneficial to Australian business and industry, and Australian business and industry have wanted us to be involved in this because it does give Australian firms procurement opportunities and, of course, some guarantees against political considerations.

We believe that this can also flow on and benefit people within Australia in regard to employment opportunities. If businesses in Australia believe that they can have better opportunities because we are involved at this level, then I think a direct link can be drawn to benefits here within the Australian community. As a government, this is our bill and we support it, and we take on board the comments of people who have contributed here in the Main Committee today.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor‐General recommending appropriation announced.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Institute of Criminology: Funding Cuts

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney‐General, upon notice, on 16 October 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that cuts in funding to the Australian Institute of Criminology (AIC) announced in the Budget will reduce the number of projects that the AIC can fulfil; if so, will the Violence Against Women Project be affected.
(2) Is violence against women in Australian society today an issue which should be addressed; if so, will he provide additional funding for this project in order to allow the project to be completed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Funding for research on the criminal justice response to violence against women which was part of the previous Government's Justice Statement was discontinued in the 1996/97 budget. I am advised by the Australian Institute of Criminology (AIC) that it has terminated the Violence Against Women Indicators Project (VAWIP) and will publish the material collected to date.
Project work in the AIC is under regular review. At present no reduction in the number of current projects, other than VAWIP, is planned.

(2) Violence against women in Australian society today is an important issue that will be addressed by my portfolio under the `National Campaign Against Violence and Crime'. There is clearly a need to collect and publish good quality data on domestic violence and develop best practice recommendations.

The priorities to be pursued will be determined following consideration of recommendations from the National Domestic Violence Forum, which was held recently, and demonstration projects suggested by the Lead Ministers' national Anti‐Crime Strategy Group.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 5 November 1996:

BREAK.PARA: (1) How many permanent residency visas have been issued to Hong Kong residents since 1991.
(2) How many recipients have not exercised their visa entitlement.
(3) How many multiple entry visas have been issued to Hong Kong residents.
(4) Do permanent residency visas include family members; if so, how many persons are involved.
(5) Has China been paid to facilitate the repatriation of `boat people'.
(6) Have sums been paid in respect of deported Chinese citizens; if so (a) why and (b) what sum was paid (i) in total and (ii) per head.
(7) Will the Government formulate a 5 year plan for immigration numbers to replace the current annual program; if so, when.
(8) How many Asian born and Asian Australian born persons are there in Australia.
(9) What definition of Asian is used in answer to part (8).
(10) Did he state on 28 October 1996 that a population level of 23 million would be accepted by most Australians; if so, when will this level be reached.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) 35,150—for the period 1 July 1991—31 October 1996 (Note: This figure excludes refugee and humanitarian applicants.)
(2) 1043—for the same period.

(3) 14,992—for the period 1 January 1991—22 November 1996. (Note: This question has been interpreted to mean Resident Return visas (RRVs). The figure refers to RRVs granted to Hong Kong passport holders.)

(4) The answer to question (1) includes family members who have been granted permanent residency visas. The number of principal applicants for those visa applications was 18,373. The number of family members was 16,777.

(5) Australia and the PRC signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) on 25 January 1995 concerning the return of Sino‐Vietnamese refugees under the safe third country provisions of the Migration Act. Sino‐Vietnamese refugees who have previously been permanently settled in China are returned to China after their identity has been verified.

Under the terms of the MOU, the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs is responsible for the return of verified Sino‐Vietnamese refugees to China by air and meeting all associated costs.
(6) No sums are paid to China in respect of the repatriation of boat people who are Chinese citizens.

(8) The estimated number of Asian‐born persons in Australia at 30 June 1995 was 866,000 or 4.8 per cent of the total population. Information on the second‐generation is obtained fromthe Census question on birthplace of parents. According to the 1991 Census (the most recent Census for which information is available), approximately 202,000, or 1.2 per cent of Australia's population was second‐generation Australian of Asian background (defined as persons born in Australia with at least one parent born in Asia).

(9) Countries are classified according to the ABS Classification of Countries for Social Statistics (ASCCSS) which defines `Asia' as including the regions of Southeast Asia, Northeast Asia and Southern Asia (see table below):

(10) In an interview on Channel 7's Face to Face program on Sunday 27 October 1996, I commented that a population of 23 million `as a plateau would not be seen as unreasonable by many Australians' in response to the suggestion put to me that 23 million might be an appropriate population level. As I said at the time, the Government does not have a population target for Australia. Rather, and this point was also made during the interview, this comment was made in the context of promoting public discussion of the issue of population levels.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) recently published projections of Australia's population for the period 1995‐2051. These projections range between a population of 20.1 million to 26 million by 2051.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney‐General and Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 6 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many appeals against decisions of the Child Support Agency (CSA) have been lodged with the Family Law Court of Australia since the introduction of review officers in the CSA.
(2) How many appeals have been heard.
(3) How many and what percentages of appeals were (a) successful and (b) unsuccessful.
(4) What fee is charged by the Court for an appeal to be lodged.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Proceedings in relation to decisions of the Child Support Agency (CSA) come to the Family Court of Australia by way of an application or appeal filed on a Form 63 or an appeal from a decision of the child support registrar filed on a Form 64. Forms 64 are used for appeals against incorrect assessments under section 110 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act, appeals against the Child Support Registrar's decision to refuse to accept a child agreement made under section 132 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act or appeals against a decision made by the Child Support Registrar in relation to an objection made pursuant to sections 82‐85 of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act. Forms 63 are used for all other Child Support applications to the Family Court. The same position applies in relation to child support matters in the Family Court of Western Australia.
Statistics on the numbers of Forms 63 and 64 filed with the Family Court of Australia, since the introduction of review officers in the CSA during 1992, are as follows:
Year Forms 63 Filed Forms 64 Filed
Comparable statistics on the numbers of Forms 63 and 64 filed with the Family Court of Western Australia for the same periods are as follows:
Year Forms 63 Filed Forms 64 Filed
1995‐96 not available not available

However, the majority of Forms 63 filed are applications for departures from administrative assessments made under section 116 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act or for substitution orders made under section 125 of the Child Support (Assessment) Act. While data on the number of appeals filed on Forms 63 are not available, the anecdotal view is that there have been very few—perhaps less than 20 across Australia.

In addition, there have been a number of appeals and applications for leave to appeal to the Full Court of the Family Court of Australia in relation to child support issues. There were two Full Court appeals relating to child support issues lodged in 1995‐96. The number of Full Court appeals raising child support issues prior to 1995‐96 is not available as they were included with `other issues' in the Court's statistical records and it would be too resource intensive to justify manually examining each of the files to seek to ascertain the information. Issues raised in applications for leave to appeal to the Full Court were not identifies separately in the statistics prior to July 1996.
(2) Information on the number of appeals filed on Forms 63 and 64 which were heard is not available.
Two Full Court appeals relating to child support issues were heard in 1995‐96.

(3) Information on the percentage of appeals filed on Forms 63 or 64 that were (a) successful and (b) unsuccessful is not available. Statistics kept by the Child Support Agency show that there is an active caseload of approximately 400,000, of which 800 have been varied by a court order. Whether these variations are as a result of orders made by the Family Court of Australia, by the Family Court of Western Australia or by Magistrates Courts, and whether they were made pre or post the introduction of review officers in the CSA, cannot be determined without a manual examination of each file which would be too resource intensive to justify undertaking.
Both of the Full Court appeals relating to child support issues heard in 1995‐96 were successful in that they were allowed.

(4) In respect of the relevant years no fee was charged by the Family Court of Australia, the Family Court of Western Australia or Magistrates Courts for the filing of a Form 63 or Form 64 or an application for leave to appeal to the Full Court, Between 1 January 1990 and 31 December 1995 a court fee of $500 was payable in respect of any appeal to the Full Court of the Family Court lodged under section 94 of the Family Law Act. From 1 January 1996 that fee rose to $616.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action will Australia be taking as a result of the June 1996 Leipzig conference relating to global genetic diversity in plants.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation's estimate that half of the world's gene stores is in such a debilitated state of refrigeration that they are unable to fulfil the basic conservation role; if so, will the Government be responding to this estimate; if so, how.
(3) Will these issues be considered in the context of Australia's ongoing aid program.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

BREAK.PARA: (1) The June 1996 Leipzig International Conference on Plant Genetic Resources, which Australia attended, recognised the importance of plant genetic resources for food and agriculture, in particular for the food security of present and future generations. The Conference recognised the serious threats to the security of plant genetic resources and acknowledged that efforts to conserve, develop, and sustainably use genetic diversity should be improved. A significant outcome of the Conference was the adoption of The Global Plan of Action for the Conservation and Sustainable Utilisation of the World's Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture.
My colleague, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, has broad responsibility for Australia's policy response to issues relating to plant genetic resources for food and agriculture.

Following the Leipzig Conference, the Australian aid program will continue to support activities and organisations which aim to conserve, develop, and sustainably use genetic diversity. Through AusAID and the Australian Centre for International Agricultural Research (ACIAR), Australia provides significant financial resources to the conservation of plant genetic diversity and the development of plant genetic resources through breeding for increased crop productivity and resistance to insects and diseases. Australia also makes smaller contributions through the Grains Research and Development Corporation.

AusAID and ACIAR are increasing their investments in global genetic diversity. Together the investment in 1996‐97 is estimated to be $10 million, which represents an increase of over 50% compared to the previous year. In 1996‐97, major contributions will include:

PARA.TAB: AusAID support to International Rice Research Institute for rice conservation/improvement in Cambodia—$2.8 million (as part of a multi‐year $10.5 million project beginning financial year 1996‐97)
AusAID funding for the International Fund for Agricultural Development—$1.6 million
AusAID funding for a South Pacific Regional Forest Genetic Resources project—$.8 million (as part of a three‐year, $2.6 million project, which commenced in financial year 1995‐96)

ACIAR support to International Agricultural Research Centres (IARCs) for programs on crop genetic resources conservation and development—$1.4 million (This is 16% of the total allocation to IARCs and represents an increase over the $1.1 million provided in financial year 1995/96). These IARCs comprise:
International Rice Research Institute—Philippines
International Maize and Wheat Improvement Center—Mexico
International Center for Tropical Agriculture—Colombia
International Potato Center—Peru
International Center for Agricultural Research in Dry Areas—Syria
International Crops Research Institute for Semi‐arid Tropics—India
International Plant Genetic Resources Institute—Italy
International Centre for Research in Agroforestry—Kenya

ACIAR's bilateral program is anticipated to provide approximately the same level of funding to plant genetic resources as in financial year 1995‐96 ie $3.6 million or approximately 18% of ACIAR's bilateral research funds.

BREAK.PARA: In addition, Australia contributes to the Global Environment Facility (approximately $43 million in the 1994‐97 period), which supports, among other things, plant genetic resource activities under its biodiversity portfolio. The GEF is a multilateral financial mechanism that provides grant and concessional funds to developing countries for activities to protect the global environment

(2) This issue has not previously been raised with me, as the portfolio responsibility for such matters rests with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Nevertheless, my Department, including AusAID and ACIAR, is aware of the critical nature of the ex situ germplasm collections held in the `world's gene stores' and the necessity that these collections be adequately conserved and curated. They are the building blocks from which improved crop varieties are developed.

In providing funds to the core programs of the IARCs, the Australian aid program adopts a strategic approach which gives priority to those centres which have prime responsibility for conserving the collections of major crop species important to developing countries of our region and Australia—namely, rice, wheat, maize, grain legumes, potato, banana. In financial year 1996‐97, the custodial centres for these key staples will receive $4.6 million in support of their germplasm and agronomy programs from Australia.

However, the IARCs hold only 10% of the world's gene stores, while the remainder are held by national institutions in both industrial and developing countries. The Global Plan of Action for the Conservation and Sustainable Utilisation of the World's Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture stresses the need for adequate resources to be made available to conserve and curate these national collections, as well as the international collections of the IARCs. At this point, national governments and institutions, with the assistance of the international community, have yet to marshall the resources necessary, through national, bilateral and multilateral sources to carry out this essential task.

(3) Australia's support through AusAID and ACIAR, as reported in response to Question 1 above, confirms that the aid program continues to take positive steps to address this important issue. Obviously, there is always more that can be done, but without diversion of resources away from other priority programs, or a significant increase in the total resource base, it is not possible to do more than at present.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the ratification by Hungary, the 65th state to become a party, bring into force the Convention on the Prohibition of the Development, Production, Stockpiling and Use of Chemical Weapons and on their Destruction (Paris, 13 January 1993).
(2) Which states have signed but not ratified the Convention.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Downer, Alexander, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) On 31 October 1996, Hungary became the 65th state to ratify the Convention on the Prohibition of the Development, Production, Stockpiling and Use of Chemical Weapons and on their Destruction—also known as the Chemical Weapons Convention (CWC). This fulfilled the conditions required to trigger a 180 day countdown to entry into force of the Convention. (Article XXI of the treaty stipulates that entry into force shall occur 180 days after the date of deposit of the 65th instrument of ratification.) Entry into force will thus occur on 29 April 1997, thereby advancing significantly a long‐standing objective of Australia's foreign and security policy—the achievement of an effectively operational CWC treaty regime.

(2) As of 6 December 1996, 160 countries had signed and 66 countries had ratified the CWC. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 20 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did his Department in its annual report on Enterprise Bargaining in Australia undertake a full statistical survey of workplaces with less than 20 employees; if not, why not.

(2) If his Department does not undertake the survey referred to in part (1), will he take action to overcome this and include survey work on the coverage and nature of individual employment contracts among small businesses.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Industrial Relations; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The 1995 Australian Workplace Industrial Relations Survey (AWIRS 95) was a major data source for the 1995 Annual Report on Enterprise Bargaining in Australia. One component of AWIRS 95 was a telephone survey of 1075 workplaces with between 5 and 19 employees (the small workplace survey). This survey was representative of all workplaces in the Australian population of this size (excluding workplaces in defence, agriculture, forestry, fishing and hunting).

Because it was conducted over the phone, the number of questions that could be asked in the small workplace survey was limited. There were no questions directly asking about individual employment contracts. Workplaces with below 5 employees were not included because the structured nature of the questionnaire means it is not applicable to very small workplaces.

The AWIRS 95 small workplace survey was used in the 1995 Annual Report on Enterprise Bargaining in Australia to provide the data for the section titled `2.5: The incidence of agreements in small business workplaces' at pages 55‐56 and `Attachment 2.A: The incidence of agreements in small business workplaces' at pages 67‐73. A full analysis of all the AWIRS 95 data will be publicly released in the form of a book in mid‐1997.

AWIRS 95 is the second survey of its kind run by the Department of Industrial Relations. The first was conducted in 1990 (AWIRS 90). AWIRS 90 also included a survey of small workplaces with between 5 and 19 employees, based on a sample of 350 workplaces. The sample size was increased to 1075 for AWIRS 95 specifically to allow more precise statistics for the small business component of the small workplace population. At this stage, there are no plans for a third AWIRS.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 20 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation (AMLC) ensure that vessels used in the export of Australian livestock (a) are seaworthy in accordance with international maritime safety conventions, (b) meet the International Labour Organisation Convention 147, related conventions and protocols concerning seafarers' conditions of employment, health care and accommodation on board and (c) have crews with competency levels to operate safely and in accordance with required international standards; if so, how; if not, will the AMLC do so urgently.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation does not have responsibility for the matters raised in the honourable member's question.
Since the commencement of the trade all livestock ships carrying livestock from Australian ports to overseas destinations have been or are registered overseas.
Responsibility for compliance of these ships with respect to seaworthiness, the International Labour Organisation (ILO) Convention 147 and crew competence are the responsibility of the flag state.

All overseas registered livestock carriers are included in the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) Port State Control Program (PSC). Any matters which are found deficient during PSC inspections are either remedied or placed in the hands of those responsible for doing so i.e., either the relevant classification society or the flag state.

The purpose of PSC system is to ensure as far as reasonably possible that the vessel (a) is seaworthy in accordance with International Maritime Safety Conventions; (b) meets the ILO Convention 147 and related convention and protocol requirements concerning seafarers health and accommodation on board; (c) has a crew competent to operate the vessel safely, and (d) has the necessary personnel who are qualified in accordance with international standards.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 20 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) ensure that foreign registered vessels used in the transport of Australian wheat (a) domestically and (b) internationally are seaworthy, operated competently and provide crew with conditions of accommodation, health care and employment set out in international maritime conventions; if so, how; if not, (i) when will the AWB do so in its capacity as a significant charterer of shipping and (ii) for what period will the AWB use Ships of shame to transport wheat.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Under the provisions of the Wheat Marketing Act 1989 the Australian Wheat Board (AWB) has power to transport, and arrange for the transport of, grain.

In respect of international shipments, the AWB's standard sales contracts contain provisions to ensure that vessels chartered to load bulk wheat are in all ways suitable. The contracts require vessels to be chartered on terms set out in the Australian Wheat Charter 1990 which, in turn, requires vessels to undergo, before loading, appropriate surveys to ensure that they will be loaded and operated in accordance with international requirements concerning safety of life at sea and pollution prevention; that crew competencies are certified; and that the vessels, including crews' living quarters, are clean and rust‐free in all respects.
The charterparty also provides for vessels to be able to load according to the custom of the port, always afloat, at a safe dock, pier, wharf or berth ordered by the AWB.

The standard contracts require vessels to be classified in Lloyd's Register not lower than 100 A1, or top classification in American, French, Italian, Norwegian or other equal register, or ships not inferior to these classifications.

The standard contracts also specify that the owners of a chartered vessel guarantee that, for the duration of the relevant charterparty, the minimum terms and conditions of employment of the crew are covered by an International Transport Federation (ITF) Agreement or a bona fide trade union agreement acceptable to the ITF.
Domestic shipping of wheat is normally confined to shipments to Tasmania for which an Australian owned vessel is used.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to part (6) of question No. 839 (Hansard , 7 November 1996, page 6593), can he provide specific details of the soil types, environmental factors, munition size and type of clearance equipment mentioned in his answer.
(2) What factors would have to pertain if former firing ranges were to be developed as (a) football fields, (b) netball courts, (c) racecourses or (d) heavy vehicle parking areas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McLachlan, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Specific details of the soil types, environmental factors, munition size and type of clearance equipment cannot be given, as this depends on the particular characteristics and history of the area in question. Some of the many possible factors in relation to these aspects include:
Soil type: (a) depth for excavation; (b) consistency of soil (eg clay/sandy/rock); and (c) moisture levels.
Environmental factors: (a) hydrology; (b) temperature (eg ground freezing point); and (c) vegetation.
Munition: (a) size of munitions (eg 2000lb bomb or small mortar); (b) fusing type (level of risk); and (c) category of munition (eg white phosphorus or high explosive).
Clearance equipment: (a) type of munitions being cleared; (b) metal detection equipment; and (c) final clearance and sifting.

(2) The future development of former firing ranges, for example, as football fields, netball courts, racecourses or heavy vehicle parking areas, is not dependent on their proposed use but rather the effectiveness of the Unexploded Ordinance clearance operations. The considerations relating to munition type and size, soil types, environmental factors and clearance equipment, as outlined in response to part (1), would determine the effectiveness of clearance operations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hanson, Pauline, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 20 November 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Do applicants for refugee status receive Medicare benefits.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Wooldridge, Dr Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Applicants for refugee status that meet the definition of `Australian resident' in the Health Insurance Act 1973 are eligible for Medicare and do, therefore, receive Medicare benefits.

To meet the definition of `Australian resident' refugee applicants must hold a valid temporary visa; be an applicant for permanent residence; and either be authorised to work or have a spouse, parent or child that is an Australian citizen or the holder of a permanent visa.
